PETITION.TITLE: Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Church of Mary Queen of Peace, Lithuania
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) That the Church of Mary Queen of Peace located in Klaipeda, Lithuania, was the only Church built in Lithuania after World War II;
(2) This Church was closed by the Soviet authorities on 15 August 1960 and confiscated in 1961 under the direct order of Mr Kruschev.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs to raise with his counterpart in the USSR the great concern of many Australians that the Church of Mary Queen of Peace be restored to the religious worshippers of Klaipeda in Lithuania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Service
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Telecommunications Commission to withdraw public telegram facilities and downgrade telegram standards by:
1. planning to withdraw the 24 hour telegraph service at the Chief Telegraph Office in each capital city and in Canberra and Darwin;
2. closing country telegraph offices;
3. increasing telegram charges whilst downgrading the service;
4. withdrawing telegram operating facilities from a large number of suburban and country post offices;
5. generating serious delays in telegram delivery by reducing standards of service though centralisation of the network and reduction of operating and delivery staff,

will reduce an available means of communications in commercial enterprise, deny the opportunity for people of Australia to make contact with family and friends in times of emergency, and civil or natural disasters, particularly for the 30 per cent of Australians who are not telephone subscribers.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will take measures to ensure the maintenance of an efficient, effective public telegram service to meet the needs of the Australian people socially, publicly, commercially and in times of emergencies and civil or natural disasters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) that US, Australian and allied forces used huge amounts of toxic chemicals for military purposes, such as Agents Orange, Blue and White, in Vietnam during the war there;
(2) many of these chemicals were, and are, known to be highly dangerous to human health;
(3) Australia's Vietnam veterans and their families are suffering many severe problems which may be due to their exposure to these chemicals; and
(4) the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia has been seeking a Royal Commission for well over two years to ensure an independent investigation of these matters.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will
(a) express its support for the Royal Commission; and
(b) urge the Federal Government to establish the Royal Commission immediately.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aircraft Manufacturing Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
The Australian Aircraft Manufacturing Industry has suffered serious setbacks since its creation, because of the lack of a coherent Australian Government Policy for the industry, as illustrated by:
(a) Reduction in RAAF flying hours.
(b) Cut backs in the Grumman Tracker.
(c) Delay in the introduction of new tactical fighter.
(d) Delay in the introduction of the trainer project.
(e) Cut back on the production of the Nomad aircraft from 200 to 170.
This will further destabilise the industry and many jobs and vital skills will be lost.

We deplore the Government's decision to proceed with the proposed retrenchments and by so doing ignore the resolution passed unanimously by the Senate 'That no compulsory retrenchments of employees should take place until both houses of Parliament have debated the joint committee's report on this reference.'
The decision to go ahead with retrenchments has been made without proper consultation with employees and unions in the industry.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will reverse its recent decision to retrench initially 38 employees, followed by further retrenchments in the new year, until both houses of Parliament have considered the finding of the present Senate inquiry into Defence matters.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. It refers to files released yesterday by the Australian War Memorial and the information that apparently the Department of Defence, from 1969 until 1971 at least, placed automatically in a Defence Department file called 'Herbicides- enemy propaganda campaign' articles concerning the possible side effects of the use of herbicides in Vietnam, including such articles as the one referred to in the Canberra Times this morning, an article from the New Yorker of 7 February 1970 which I believe on anybody's reading of it would be considered to be a scientifically sound and historically correct article. Was this and is this the practice in the Minister's Department-that reports of this type and quality are put in files labelled 'Enemy propaganda campaign'? Is it the attitude of his Department that anyone who questions the use or the side effects of herbicides in Vietnam or elsewhere is indulging in an enemy campaign against this country?

—I think that this question is more properly directed to the Minister for Defence, but in respect of my own Department I am happy to say that all items of scientific value, whether they have appeared in Australian journals or those from overseas, have been collected by the library within the Department of Veterans' Affairs and stored in such a way as to make for easy reference for medical and other professional persons within our Department serving veterans. I am not sure whether the item to which Senator Grimes has referred, an item which appeared in the New Yorker, which I have not seen and about which I do not know, is included in the library of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. But I am happy to check out that matter and I will bring down a reply for Senator Grimes.

—Has the Minister for Social Security seen letters published in the Age and the Australian today expressing concern that the six-monthly indexation of social security pensions and benefits would not occur during the 12 months wage freeze? What action has been taken to inform pensioners and beneficiaries that the wage freeze will not interfere in any way with six- monthly indexation?

—My attention has been drawn to the letters which appeared in the Age and the Australian newspapers and which inquired about the possibility of the freeze affecting pensioners. I am sorry that pensioners have been put to concern. I indicated to the Senate some time ago that I had some inquiries and, as a result, issued a news release on 16 November confirming the Government's statement, which had also been made by the Treasurer, Mr Howard, that the proposed pause would not affect the indexation of pensions and benefits. That release was not given any coverage in the media. The matter was then raised in the Senate-by Senator Colston, I think. I answered a question. I re-issued a Press release. Once again, there has been little or no Press coverage of that. The letters published this morning indicate that it is a matter of public interest and, for some pensioners, a matter of concern. I welcome the question asked by Senator Bonner, because it gives me a chance again to put on the public record the fact that the Government does not propose to interfere with the indexation arrangements; that is, that the twice-yearly adjustments to most pensions and benefits which occur in November and May will proceed in the normal course. I merely use this opportunity to appeal to the media to cover that aspect of the Government's policy to avoid any unnecessary worry on the part of pensioners and beneficiaries.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the recent Australian Council of Social Service pensioner phone-in survey. The survey report has revealed the continuation of acute problems within the Social Security and Health departments in dealing with the invalid pensioner -particularly the 85 per cent eligibility rule, the insensitivity of medical officers and the severe difficulties faced by sick and elderly people forced off the invalid pension on to unsuitable benefits or none at all. Why has the Minister seen fit to continue using 'unsympathetic and hostile' medical officers -to use the report's words-to conduct pension eligibility examinations? In view of the dramatic increase in social security tribunal appeals and all the unnecessary hardship that this causes to genuine cases, why has the Minister not implemented his own Department's recommendations for medical officers to accept and practise consultation with social workers to provide a more effective and efficient assessment of invalid pensioner applications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of the invalid pension has been raised on a number of occasions. I am, of course, familiar with the phone-in which was organised by the Australian Council of Social Service and the report it prepared on the basis of the people who telephoned. It did not require the ACOSS phone-in or that recent action to get me and my Department to direct attention to the problems in the administration of the invalid pension. The matter has, of course, been raised in the Senate on a number of occasions and I have outlined the steps which have been taken to remove the difficulties which have been experienced.

ANSWER.PARA: I notice that Senator Elstob referred to me personally in his question when he asked: Why has the Minister seen fit to continue using unsympathetic doctors? The position is that the doctors used are medical officers under the supervision of the Department of Health. In other words, we go to the Department of Health for the medical assessment which is required as part of our obtaining information to decide whether someone is incapable of work. I do not accept that there is a general use of unsympathetic doctors. Of course I cannot deny that some doctors may not be sympathetic. The difficulty in dealing with the sort of allegation which has been made by ACOSS, and which is repeated by the honourable senator, is the lack of specific complaint. On a number of occasions I have asked ACOSS to be particular in the complaints it makes so that they can be followed up properly. The Australian Council of Social Service has declined to give us the particulars which would enable us to check individual cases. I can say only that the Government has no wish to use people in this area who are not sympathetic to the claimants. I have no direct, hard evidence that any particular doctors who act as Commonwealth medical officers are not behaving in a proper way. I suggest that if there is any such evidence it be given to me, my Department, the Department of Health or the Minister for Health.

I think Senator Elstob's information about the increase in appeals might be a little out of date. I have previously commented in the Senate on the fact that there is a larger number of appeals than we would wish, particularly in both Queensland and New South Wales, that we have been tackling the question of the primary decision making-in other words, trying to reduce the number of decisions which give rise to appeals-and that we have been acting to streamline the appeals procedure. I recently gave some statistics to Senator Colston who raised questions about the delay being experienced in Queensland. I think the present position would be that the number of appeals is declining, rather than increasing, as we direct more attention to the improvement of primary decision making.

As far as the last part of the question is concerned, it was not absolutely clear to me just what recommendations of my Department it is said I have not followed. I can say that some discussions have been held on whether the Department ought to revert to having its own medical officers. The advice which I have been tendered-my own view is the same-is that we should not go into the business of having our own separate set of medical practitioners for social security matters. I think that would be inefficient and costly and would not advance the cause of the invalid pensioner. If that is not the point of the honourable senator's question, he might look at the Hansard 'pinks' of his question and my reply and either ask me another question tomorrow or place a question on notice. The general position is that we use medical practitioners through the Department of Health. We are in the process of producing a rather more detailed form for the use of doctors conducting those medical examinations, which I think will more accurately document the non-medical and social factors which are relevant to these cases. We certainly intend to continue trying to improve our decision making in this area.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CONVENTION ON THE LAW OF THE SEA

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As Australia is one of the very few nations intending to sign the Law of the Sea treaty, could the Minister tell me what arguments convinced us that it would be in our best interests to sign this treaty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that about 118 countries have signed the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea this year. Some countries did not sign it or deferred a decision on signature for a variety of reasons. In some cases, this was due to deficiencies that they saw in Part 11 of the Convention dealing with mining of the deep sea bed. We also have some difficulties with Part 11 but have taken the view that the overall benefits of the Convention outweigh its disadvantages. Australia continues to hope that the Convention will come to be universally supported and provide an agreed framework for all aspects of the use of the seas. The principal reason why we became a signatory to it is that there is a necessity for an agreed framework for the use of the seas and all aspects of that. As was stated or implied in Senator Watson' s question, some countries have not signed it. For instance, the British Government has referred in its statement on signature to the possibility of amendment of the Convention in ways that would make it more generally acceptable . If realistic proposals to this end could be devised, this would obviously have our closest attention.

ANSWER.PARA: Another aspect to take into account is that, as we consider ratification of the Convention, we would be looking at any aspects of our position that unfolded as a result of other nations' approach to it or recommendations that were put forward. Having given very close consideration to the desirability of having a law of the sea convention, with as many countries as possible becoming signatories to it, we considered that at this stage we would become a signatory to it. Most of our neighbours have signed the Convention. I will see whether the Minister for Foreign Affairs wishes to detail any particular arguments, as requested by Senator Watson. But, in general terms, we see the desirability of the application of the law of the sea amongst the countries which would need to work together in its use. Subject to any particular amendments that we may wish to raise during the ratification process, I think it is a desirable objective to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer a question concerning bank profits. I have given her a broad hint that I might ask this question. I refer to the substantial profits of banks during 1980-81, most of which represented increases in the order of 25 per cent to 30 per cent. Is she aware that, in contrast to most other industries, the profits of most banks and other financial institutions have continued to grow unabated during 1981-82? I refer also to finance institutions such as Custom Credit Corporation Ltd which reported a profit increase of 26 per cent to $30.8m in the last year. Is she aware that banks-including, astonishingly, the Commonwealth Bank-further increase the effective rate of interest to borrowers by making additional charges called 'service fees' and a whole host of other imposts in addition to interest and normal bank charges? Does she agree that banks and all other lending institutions should be required to cease immediately all charges except interest and a service account charge so that the hapless borrowers who have no way of disputing these extra imposts can budget for their commitments and so that banks which enjoy a part-monopoly because of legislation of this Parliament cannot, by sneaky and surreptitious means, increase the real rate of interest being charged to their customers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to obtain more specific information on some aspects of Senator Chipp's question. But, as I am advised at present, bank profits in Australia in 1981-82 have not kept pace with inflation. Indeed, profits from banking operations of the three major private banks and the Commonwealth Bank have declined in nominal terms in 1981-82. Bank charges are related to the cost of the individual services provided. If bank charges were lowered, banks would have to raise interest rates charged to borrowers. One measure of protection afforded to depositors is the level of capital reserves available in bank balance sheets. As profits are the major source of resources, profits must keep pace with inflation if capital reserves are not to be depleted and depositor protection endangered. As I said, there are some specific matters on which I am not yet advised and I will advise Senator Chipp as soon as possible.

—I ask a supplementary question which arises out of the Minister's answer. I ask: Does she agree that bank profits in 1980-81 rose by 25 per cent to 30 per cent and that they have continued unabated in the same fashion in 1981 -82? Does she also agree that the Custom Credit Corporation reported a profit increase last year of 26 per cent, namely, $30.8m? Is she saying that the Department of the Treasury is asserting that the rate of inflation in Australia now is between 25 per cent and 35 per cent? If she is not asserting that, what else does her answer mean?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am certainly not asserting the last point raised by Senator Chipp with regard to the level of inflation because that is obviously not an accurate statement of the level of inflation in 1981-82. As I said earlier, I am advised that the bank profits in Australia in 1981-82 have not kept pace with inflation. Indeed, the banking operations of the three major private banks and the Commonwealth Bank declined in nominal terms in 1981-82. That is the information as I have it. As I said, I will seek further information with regard to the other matters raised by Senator Chipp in his detailed question and advise him as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. In view of the article in the Sydney Morning Herald entitled 'Justice Murphy criticises diversion of funds', will the Minister, for I believe the hundredth time, explain to the Senate and all who want to listen and understand the system of funding of government and private schools by the present Federal Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I saw the article in which certain remarks were attributed to Mr Justice Murphy. He is, of course, not the only member of the Senate who has the record of having been a pupil at a New South Wales public school and he is not the only one who is proud of his time at a New South Wales public school. I do not think his assertions on funding are correct, but in any case I will answer Senator Lajovic's question briefly by reiterating that there are three partners in the funding of education in Australia. The three partners are the Commonwealth Government, the State governments and non-government sources, private sources. When one adds together the inputs from the three partners in education funding, the figures that emerge show that at the secondary level the government secondary schools have the greatest number of dollars to spend and the government secondary schools have the best pupil-teacher ratios.

ANSWER.PARA: On that basis alone there are no grounds for asserting that government schools in Australia are disadvantaged. They run a good system, well supplied with resources and with appropriately small class sizes. Those who do not recognise those facts simply do not want to recognise what the truth is. The truth is that , when the contributions of the three funding partners are taken into account, the government schools in Australia are well resourced. If one looks at the non- government schools, one finds that that is where the poverty is in education, particularly in the Catholic school system. There are large class sizes and small inputs of dollars. Even for the independent non-government schools, the non-Catholic ones, the resource inputs are generally less than or at about the same level as those of government schools.

People tend to confuse the assets which schools have available with the income and resources which they have available to run them from year to year. The assets have been built up over generations. The amount of money available to run the schools is what the debate is about and in that debate there is no validity to the claim that the government system is disadvantaged or that it is failing.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I preface it by saying that no doubt he is aware that heart attacks are still a major cause of death throughout this country. I refer to a recent newspaper article headed 'Heart attacks-Aspirin new hope'. In that article it was detailed that a study of some 1,300 men suggested that an aspirin a day cuts in half the chance of having a heart attack, due, most probably, to the aspirin's known ability to inhibit blood clotting. Will the Minister comment on such use of aspirin and ask the Minister for Health to issue guidelines based upon research into this matter that has been carried out already throughout the world in the way of using aspirin as a preventative against such serious things as heart attacks? Perhaps also it could be used in helping to prevent cataracts in people as they get older, particularly if they have diabetes.

—I am aware that certain drugs make blood platelets less sticky and to that extent can have a beneficial effect on things like heart attacks and certain vascular diseases. I am really not able to say whether an aspirin a day is something that people should be using widely. I will certainly refer that to the Minister whom I represent. I imagine that the manufacturers of salicylates will be very pleased to hear the question and to think that they may in fact get a widespread market. I reiterate that the factors to which we have to be directing most attention if we are serious about reducing heart attacks in Australia-after all, this is the single largest cause of death among adults-is to control high blood pressure, to reduce the incidence of smoking, to get people to keep their weight under control and, most importantly, to get them to select carefully the genes which they inherit; in other words, to choose their parents well. If they can do those things heart attacks should diminish overnight.
—May I suggest that the Minister also inquire to see whether the aspirin should be taken before or after the apple.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. In view of the recommendation of the national International Year of Disabled Persons evaluation conference in Canberra in 1982 that there was an immediate need for the establishment of an independent and representative voice of Australians with disabilities, I ask the Minister: What is the Government doing to resource the establishment of Disabled Persons International in Australia directly to enable its independent organisation and activities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that the Commonwealth supports a number of umbrella organisations in the social welfare field. It supports the Australian Council of Social Service, which acts as the representative body for some 2,500 welfare organisations which are affiliated with it. It funds ACROD, the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of the Disabled, which performs a similar function for organisations which deal with people with disability. We also fund ACOTA, Australian Council on The Ageing, at a Commonwealth level and the Australian Early Childhood Association. The general policy which has been followed by the Commonwealth in this area is to fund umbrella organisations rather than the myriad single organisations which exist. I think it was the University of New South Wales which said that there are some 37,000 welfare organisations around Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite clearly it would become a very difficult matter if the Commonwealth were expected to have direct funding responsibility with such a plethora of organisations. With respect to Disabled Persons International, I think that the move which gained such strength during IYDP to have disabled people speaking on their own behalf is one of particular significance. Therefore, I have been concerned to try to do what I can, consistent with the policies that we follow in this area, to help Disabled Persons International to become established. In that regard we made some money available to assist disabled Australians to go to Singapore for an international meeting. Recently I have had correspondence from DPI which has requested assistance with respect to, I think, a national conference.

Consistent with the general attitude we have to support of organisations, I have examined that proposal and I have asked my Department to examine it further with a view to seeing whether some form of assistance could be provided for that meeting. I would hope that the assistance would come through and from ACROD rather than directly from the Government because of the policy which I outlined in the earlier part of my answer. I express the view that Disabled Persons International is an important development in the field of advocacy for the disabled in Australia. Subject to the concern that I have to maintain a direct Commonwealth funding relationship with umbrella organisations and not with, as I say, the tens of thousands of organisations which exist in the various social welfare fields, I hope that we will be able to do something to advance the cause of DPI in Australia.

It provides a supplement to the wage cost of somebody who has been unemployed for a considerable time. That supplement is available to people who have been out of employment. Until very recently it was restricted to the young unemployed. I think the Minister has recently announced a wider approach to it. Schemes of this sort need to be administered very carefully because they are open to abuse. Sometimes one reads of complaints that the scheme is being used not to subsidise additional employment but merely to reduce the costs of employment which would have occurred anyway. That is not the object of the scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: I have discussed that with Mr Macphee and he is satisfied, I think, that the monitoring of the program is adequate and that it is applied to create employment. Certainly it has been effective in obtaining employment for people the greater proportion of whom stay in employment at the end of the subsidy period. I think that is an important indicator of its success. I was not familiar with the restriction against family involvement, but I can imagine that this is, again, simply one of the measures one takes to try to avoid the abuse of public moneys. I can see that if one allowed the general employment of people in a family the scheme could be open to abuse. If the honourable senator has evidence that this is causing hardship in cases where in his view a subsidy would be appropriate I suggest that he draw the particular circumstances to the attention of the Minister to enable the point that he has raised to be considered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware that 500 Ngaanatjara Aborigines from Western Australia's central desert region trekked 1,500 kilometres to Perth to discuss with the Western Australian Government a land rights claim to allow them freehold title to the 3 million hectare central reserve which they occupy and that their claim was flatly refused by the Western Australian Premier? Is the Minister further aware that these people have now stated that they will take their case to the Prime Minister to get his help? I ask whether the Minister can assure the Senate that the Federal Government will dissociate itself from Premier O'Connor's statement in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I have no intention of splitting Western Australia into two sections, one for whites and one for coloureds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —While it is true that Aboriginals in Western Australia do not hold freehold title to the reserves, they have a title which can be altered only by affirmative action by the Parliament of Western Australia. There is a very real protection for them in the kind of tenure which they hold, and this is often forgotten. Aboriginal reserves represent about 8 per cent of the area of Western Australia. As I say, affirmative action by the Western Australian Parliament would be required to alter the tenure. I understand that, for some years, the Pitjantjatjara people generally-Senator McIntosh referred in his question to the Ngaanatjara people-have been seeking land rights over the areas traditionally associated with the Pitjantjatjara people of Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory. Of course, they regard themselves as one people with one language and one land. They have been consistently opposed to divisions in land tenure arrangements which have resulted through the accident that some of them are in the Northern Territory, some in South Australia and some in Western Australia where different arrangements apply.

ANSWER.PARA: As early as 1976, the Commonwealth took the initiative at a meeting of the Aboriginal Advisory Council to urge the Ministers concerned to investigate the manner in which a common land rights title for the central reserve areas could be given to the Pitjantjatjara people. I understand that the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs argued for the implementation of this proposal through State and Commonwealth legislation, pointing out, of course, that the Commonwealth had already laid the basis with the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. Subsequently, there has been the enactment of the Pitjantjatjara land rights legislation in 1981 in South Australia. Therefore, the problem is one that concerns Western Australia.

As I say, the tenure arrangements in Western Australia are more secure than is generally realised. I understand that the Western Australian Government has consistently maintained that its Act-the Aboriginal Affairs Planning Authority Act-provides the best possible protection for Aboriginals for reasons which I have set out already in my answer. Accordingly, the State Government will not consider granting freehold title in respect of Aboriginal reserves administered under that Act. That is what I understand the position to be. I read in the newspapers that there had been a march and that there had been a meeting. I understand that the Western Australian Premier, Mr O'Connor, reiterated the State Government's policy of maintaining the existing status of the reserves. I simply say once again that an Act of the Western Australian Parliament would be required to change the tenure of reserves and for that reason tenure is secure. It would require a very public decision and a very public declaration if anyone wished to diminish the rights of the Aboriginal people who are involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Leader of the Government in the Senate seen the editorial in this morning's Australian Financial Review headed 'Indonesia and Australia'? Does the Government agree that some Australian Labor Party and other selective moralising about Indonesia and East Timor has caused unnecessary trouble between Australia and Indonesia? Is the Government evidence similar to that of the Australian Financial Review editorial which absolutely denies the story of famine in East Timor? Does the Government accept that 'the Indonesians have made it very clear that they want to open a new chapter in sensible, mutually beneficial relations between our two countries'? Finally, is it time for Australians to show that they can stop preaching and practise the virtues of charity and reconciliation as well as truthfulness and good sense?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the editorial, which seeks to make the point that it is important that there should be better and closer relations and understanding between Indonesia and Australia. I think that it is a timely reminder to all Australians that this should be so. Indonesia, our nearest neighbour, has some 140 million people and this number will increase to some 200 million by the turn of the century. It is a stable, non-communist country which plays a very important role in not only the Association of South East Asian Nations but also the Western Pacific generally. Its role will become increasingly important. I have observed, having travelled very widely in many parts of Indonesia over a lifetime, the very rapid uplifting of the living standards of its people in the last 20 or 30 years in the face of enormous difficulties posed by its having some 3,000 islands stretched over a distance of 2,000 miles. I believe that Indonesia is making very strong efforts in that regard and wants to bring to its people higher living standards. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill amends the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 to repeal section 14 of that Act. Section 14 of the Act imposes an obligation on the Minister not to take action which is inconsistent with the obligations of Australia under international agreements relating to trade. The repeal of this section is principally designed to remove for practical purposes the grounds for any application to the Australian Courts raising the issue of Australia's non- compliance with international agreements, including the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Codes and any bilateral agreements, relating to anti-dumping and countervailing duty action.

The provisions of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act enable the Government to take anti-dumping and countervailing duty action against imports. Both actions are designed to offset export prices which are not established on a fair commercial basis. Australia is a signatory to the GATT and the related Codes which establish rules of conduct for anti-dumping and countervailing actions. The Codes, which elaborate on the relevant provisions of the GATT, were part of the outcome of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations, Tokyo Round, concluded in 1979. Australia acceded to the Subsidies and Countervailing Duties Code on 21 September 1982 and to the Anti-Dumping Code on 21 October 1982.

The Codes require that signatories must take all necessary steps to ensure that their domestic legislation conforms with the provisions of the Codes. The Customs Tariff (Anti-dumping) Act was amended in 1981 so that it conforms with the codes. Anti-dumping or countervailing duties cannot be imposed unless it is determined by the relevant authority in the importing country that the goods in question have been dumped, that is, exported at less than normal prices in the country of export, or subsidised and as a result, an industry in the importing country has been injured or threatened with injury. The Codes also limit the extent of countervailing or anti-dumping action to an amount equal to the amount of subsidy or of dumping or the extent to which injury is occurring, whichever is the lesser.

Where a preliminary affirmative finding of dumping or subsidization is made by the Department of Industry and Commerce as the relevant authority, and there is evidence of material injury or threat of material injury to the domestic industry, the GATT Anti-Dumping and Subsidies and Countervailing Duties Codes permit the taking of provisional action in the form of securities which in Australia, are taken under the provisions of section 42 of the Customs Act. The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act has facilitated proceedings for injunctive relief in these matters before the Federal Court of Australia. The related Customs Securities (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill which I will introduce shortly contains a provision to remove from the scope of that Act decisions to take securities under the Customs Act as provisional anti-dumping and countervailing measures. That provision will supersede the regulations with similar effect introduced on 24 November 1982.

In the injunction proceedings before the Court exporters of goods to Australia have used the provisions of section 14 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act as the basis for arguing that the method by which the Department proceeds to the decisions to require provisional anti-dumping and provisional counter-vailing measures is contrary to Australia's international obligations. Whilst the Department meets the requirements of the Codes in principle these arguments have nevertheless enabled interim injunctions to be obtained. As a consequence the Department has been prevented from taking provisional securities and this has operated to the detriment of Australian industry.

The world wide economic recession has led to a dramatic increase in the number of dumping and countervailing complaints in Australia. The Government is therefore concerned that there should be no impediment to taking quick and effective action to combat unfair trading practices which operate to the detriment of Australian industry.

The repeal of section 14 of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act, as proposed by this Bill, will not effect Australia's adherence to the relevant international obligations. The Government's view is that issues concerning Australia's obligations under the international agreements relating to anti- dumping and countervailing duty action are more appropriately considered within the context of the dispute settlement provisions of the particular agreements rather than in the Australian Courts. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of this Bill is twofold. It amends the Customs Act to place beyond doubt that securities may be validly taken under section 42 of that Act for the purposes of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. It also amends the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act to remove from the scope of that Act decisions made under section 42 of the Customs Act to require and take securities in respect of duty that may be payable under the Customs Tariff (Anti -Dumping) Act.

The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act is the legislation which enables the Government to take anti-dumping and countervailing duty action against imports. This action is designed to offset export prices which are not established on a fair commercial basis.

Where a preliminary affirmative finding of dumping or subsidisation is made by the Department of Industry and Commerce and there is evidence of material injury or threat of material injury to the domestic industry, provisional action in the form of securities may be taken under the provisions of section 42 of the Customs Act.
The securities are held in accordance with the time limits specified in the Customs Act until, after inquiry, a final decision is made as to whether dumping or countervailing duties are warranted.

If the final decision is in the affirmative the securities held are adjusted to the amount of the duty to be imposed. If the decision is that dumping or countervailing duty is not warranted the securities are returned to depositors.

As a consequence of litigation in the Federal Court the department has been restrained from taking provisional anti-dumping and countervailing securities in respect of the importation of certain goods into Australia.
It has been argued in these proceedings that the terms of section 42 of the Customs Act do not authorise the taking of security for the purpose of protecting Australian industry.

The amendments in Clause 4 of the Bill provide an express link between section 42 of the Customs Act and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. This is proposed to remove any doubt as to the validity of requiring securities under the Customs Act for the purposes of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act.

In my Second Reading Speech relating to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 I explained how exporters of goods to Australia have been able to use the existing law to prevent the Department from taking provisional securities.

The provisions of Clause 6 of the Bill are designed to minimise the opportunities to prevent the taking of such securities. Under this clause decisions relating to the taking of the securities will be exempted from the scope of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

Regulations with similar effect to this clause became operative on 24 November 1982. The provisions in this Bill will however, supersede those regulations and it is the Governnemt's intention that the regulations will be repealed after this Bill receives the Royal Assent.

The Government believes that the removal from judicial review of decisions on provisional securities is essential if anti-dumping and countervailing measures are to be effective in combatting unfair international trading practices which operate to the detriment of Australian industry.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-

On 28 October 1982 the Senate amended the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No . 2) 1982 to delete provisions that would have prevented State and Territory Governments from levying special taxes on health insurance organisations registered under the National Health Act. On the same day the Minister for Health moved that the House of Representatives agree to the amendments so that the Bill could pass and the substantial benefits provided for in that legislation would not be delayed.

At the time, the Minister foreshadowed that the Government would reintroduce the deleted provisions. The Bill now before the Senate contains those provisions . I draw the attention of the Senate to clauses 4 and 6 which preclude the application by any State or Territory of any tax based on or calculated by reference to any matter connected with the business of health insurance. A tax based on the number of contributors or the amount of contributions would be such a tax.

As indicated during the debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) , the Victorian Government has imposed a levy on health insurance organisations in that State. That levy is at the rate of 80c per week per family contributor and 40c per week per single contributor for basic hospital tables. It has been imposed since 1 August 1982. The levy purports to finance outpatient services provided to insured persons.

As a further development, the New South Wales Parliament passed legislation on 2 December 1982 to impose an identical levy to Victoria for outpatient services from 1 January 1983. However, the New South Wales Government has gone a step further; it has introduced an additional levy to finance a service that is in no way related to the scope of the basic hospital benefits table, namely, the New South Wales Ambulance Service. The ambulance levy to be effective from 1 February 1983 is at the rate of 60c per week per family contributor and 30c per week per single contributor for basic hospital benefits. There is a total levy on hospital funds in New South Wales of $1.40 a week family and 70c a week for single contributors.
I believe I should once again place before the Senate the main principles at stake in the legislation.

As I indicated during the debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), this issue raises directly the division of responsibilities between the State and Federal Governments for the hospital systems.

In September last year the Federal Government introduced new funding arrangements for State hospitals. In all States but South Australia and Tasmania it abandoned the 50-50 cost-sharing arrangements which the Jamison Commission said had 'rewarded the expensive and punished the efficient'. Under the cost- sharing scheme the States were reluctant to accept managerial and planning responsibility for their hospital systems. Because financial responsibility was divided the States had not, in general, bothered to manage their hospitals efficiently.

The changes made last year have been effective in this regard. The States have, in general, begun to make the difficult managerial decisions necessary for efficient hospital systems. There have been difficulties in the transitional phase. There have been disagreements over the revenue-raising capacity of some of the States. The Commonwealth viewed their difficulties sympathetically at the premiers' conference, although some states-most notably Victoria-believed they should have been more generously treated.

One of Victoria's and New South Wales' major problems has been the institution of an effective revenue collection system for its hospitals, particularly for outpatient services. In communications with the Federal Government the Minister for Health, Mr Roper, has acknowledged that this is an administrative and managerial problem. He has referred to this 'incapacity of Victorian hospitals to devote the requisite resources to the pursuit of fees for all chargeable occasions of (outpatient) service'. The Minister for Health for New South Wales, Mr Brereton, acknowledges that the same problems apply to New South Wales hospitals.

Apparently unable to implement the necessary mechanisms, the Victorian and New South Wales governments decided to abolish outpatient charges for insured patients, and to impose a special levy on them through insurance funds. As stated earlier, New South Wales has decided it will also finance its ambulance services this way.

The Federal Government cannot object to the Victorian and New South Wales governments' decisions to abolish outpatient charges for insured patients, although it considers it to be an unwise course. The Government's concern is with the particular mechanism these State governments have adopted to finance the resulting revenue shortfall. They have selected a discriminatory tax on a particular group of their residents-those who have been prudent enough to take out health insurance.

The State governments can charge for their outpatient services in whatever way they like, provided they meet the shortfall out of their own funds. Victoria and New South Wales are free to fund their hospitals, as Queensland does, from general taxation or other revenue. The objection of the Federal Government is to this discriminatory levy on those who have health insurance with a registered health insurance organization.

In adopting this course the Victorian and New South Wales governments have exceeded their responsibility for hospital funding and encroached on health insurance which is the Commonwealth's constitutional responsibility. Parliament has given the Federal Minister for Health power to declare standard hospital fees for health insurance purposes. To protect the insured and to prevent the abuse of the insurance system, the Federal Minister has power to determine the benefit liability and contribution rates of funds.

The imposition of a levy on the funds by Victoria has altered their financial situation, pushed up contribution rates and reduced the Commonwealth's ability to meet its obilgations to health insurance contributors. The same will now apply in New South Wales.

The Government is also particularly concerned for those pensioners who, though entitled to free health care, have insured themselves in order to have choice of doctor while in hospital. These people, who are already paying for that privilege, now find themselves having to pay an additional cost imposed by the Victorian Government. This unfortunate effect of the levy was brought to the attention of the Government in correspondence from Victorian pensioners who found themselves in this position. Pensioners in New South Wales with basic hospital insurance will be worse off. In addition to the outpatient levy, they will have to find 60c or 30c per week extra for the ambulance levy.

I would repeat that although the Federal Government acknowledges the power of the Victorian and New South Wales Governments to abolish direct charging for health services, and to replace them with a general tax on their residents, it does not consider it a sound course of action. The implementation of the user- pays principle has had a clear impact on hospital utilisation rates and the abolition of this discipline in Victoria and New South Wales must contribute to an excessive use of very costly and scarce resources.

Another of the Federal Government's major concerns has been with the fact that the Victorian levy will raise revenue in excess of that required to pay the utilisation of outpatient services by those with health insurance.

The Commonwealth has estimated that the total annual income to the Victorian Government from this levy will be $44m. Again, on our best estimates, if the Victorian Government were collecting all the outpatient revenue that it should from insured patients by individual charging, it would be collecting $31m at the current level of charges. At this point I should advise honourable senators that further increases in hospital charges in Victoria will occur from 1 March 1983. There is no indication of whether the levy rate will increase. There is a difference of $13m involved, an important $13m since it is a direct tax on the insured to pay for other aspects of the Victorian health system.

Victoria says that it has suffered in the Grants Commission and the Premier's conference. Very well, let it take the matter up through the established mechanisms like every other State. That course is open to the Victorian Government. I cannot guarantee that it will be successful.

In relation to New South Wales, our estimates indicate that the amount of revenue will be raised by the outpatient levy will closely approximate the amount the Commonwealth estimates should otherwise be raised in that State by individual outpatient charges. However, this in no way detracts from the principles applicable to Victoria as I have stated above. That is, this levy cuts across the Commonwealth's responsibility in administering the health insurance system and runs contrary to the user-pays principle.

The ambulance levy in New South Wales raises different considerations. This levy does not, as I mentioned earlier, even remotely relate to the benefits available under the basic hospital table. Where will it stop? We may next see a levy on health funds to finance inpatient services with a complete breakdown of the Commonwealth's insurance arrangements.

The matter of the income tax rebate on the levy raises a very important issue. When introducing the legislation into the New South Wales Parliament to impose the levy, Mr Brereton referred to savings that would be made by current contributors to the ambulance scheme in that state because of the tax rebate that will apply to the ambulance levy. Mr Brereton has made an assumption that is by no means certain at this stage. The whole question of the tax rebate on the levies is a complex one and is being examined by the Taxation Office. If the rebate does apply to the ambulance levy then we could have a situation where the Commonwealth, and therefore taxpayers throughout Australia, are subsidising the New South Wales ambulance service to the extent of about $12m a year.
I now briefly turn to some of the specific concerns with this legislation raised during the debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982.
There has been some concern that Victoria was not treated equitably in relation to its hospital revenue-raising capacity in the discussions leading up to the Premiers' conference.

I do not accept that argument. In my opinion considerable leeway was given to all the States to enable them to cope with the transition to the state of full managerial and financial responsibility. However, the Government has made it clear here and in the other place that Victoria can raise issues relating to its share of tax revenues at Premiers' conferences. These are matters which are broader than health funding alone, and are properly matters for discussion between heads of Government and Treasurers.

I also wish to correct an error repeated several times by the opposition in the course of the earlier debates on these provisions while they were part of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) the actions of the Victorian Government do not, in any way to which the Federal Government objects, resemble the funding system of the Queensland Government for its hospitals.

What concerns the Federal Government about these levies is that they are directed at a section of the population for whom the Federal Government has particular concern, for whom it has constitutional responsibility and to whom it provides a special tax rebate-those with health insurance.

By comparison the Queensland Government funds its hospital system from the casket lottery and from general taxation revenue. I say here, as the Minister for Health has said on previous occasions in the other place, that if the Victorian Government (and also the New South Wales Government) want to fund hospitals in that way-through lotteries and from tax revenue, then the Federal Government will not stand in its way. That is entirely a matter for these States .
The Victorian Government has protested that up to 2,000 jobs could be lost if it does not make up a shortfall of $20m in health funding.

Accepting for now the $20m figure and assuming that such a shortfall were recoverable in no other way-both dubious propositions-the unemployment argument may provide a reason for some sort of tax, but it is no case at all for this very discriminatory levy. It is not a sufficient argument for this levy that workers will lose jobs if it is not imposed. Other courses are open to the Victorian Government.

However I do not accept that the Victorian and New South Wales Governments cannot collect this money. Other State hospital systems can manage it. I remind honourable senators that this levy will only collect money from the insured section of the population. It leaves those without health insurance to be billed in the same was as any ordinary commercial debt, so some billing system is already in place and will remain.

These arrangements help the Victorian and New South Wales Governments make up a shortfall that exists because it has not pursued the debts of insured patients. What sort of an administrative system, does a State have when it cannot collect debts from a limited number of insured patients? That is the question the Federal Government has been asking. It is the question the Jamison Commission asked, in effect, and it is the reason why the Federal Government in September last year gave the States full responsiblity for the expenditure of hospital funds. On this point Mr Brereton indicated that the New South Wales Government has bad debts of 10 per cent of bills raised.

In conclusion, I draw the attention of the Senate to clause 2 which provides that the Bill will come into operation on a date to be fixed by proclamation. This will allow the Victorian Government time to reintroduce individual charging systems (and for New South Wales to repeal its legislation). Finally, let me emphasise that the proposed amendments do not affect the basic responsibility of the States and the Northern Territory to determine charges for public hospitals. The pupose of the amendments is to ensure that the Federal Government has the power to carry out its full responsiblity in the area of health insurance and to protect contributors' interests.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
