I indicated that the crude oil levy and excise on petroleum had yielded to the Federal Government , over the last three years, about $12,500m and that of this sum about 15 per cent, or $1,978m, had come back to road users. I suggested that perhaps the figure of 15 per cent was far too low, that there was available sufficient money to ensure that additional taxes would not be needed to finance the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. But, of course, increased taxes will have to be paid by motorists throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the introduction of the Budget in August excise totalling 5.155c a litre was levied on petroleum products and road diesel fuel. To allow the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program to proceed that excise level was raised by 1c to 6.155c a litre. For those who were brought up on the use of the term 'gallon', that is equal to an excise of about 28c a gallon. I found that interesting because the excise alone is now more than the total amount I paid for a gallon of petrol when I began driving.

The story of the increase of 1c a litre does not end there. Next year the surcharge will be doubled, to 2c a litre, in addition to all other fuel taxes imposed. To speak in terms of one or two cents a litre, or even the 6.155c total that applies at the moment, does not illustrate what the impost really means to the Australian motorist. The Minister for National Development and Energy ( Senator Sir John Carrick) said in his second reading speech that a charge of 2c a litre would cost the average motorist, travelling 15,000 kilometres a year, about an additional 67c a week. That may not sound very much, but it amounts to some $35 a year, a significant sum when we realise that it is in addition to what the motorist is already paying.

Similarly, the Minister cited the experience of a driver of a 38-tonne truck who travels from Sydney to Melbourne, suggesting that as a result of the imposition of an extra 2c a litre he would spend an additional $18 in fuel on a round trip. Again, if the same driver undertook a return journey from Brisbane to Melbourne his fuel bill would increase by $45. It would be naive in the extreme to believe that those additional costs will not be passed on and thus have an inflationary effect on the economy.

In speaking to the Bill last Thursday I mentioned that it was a pity that steps had not been taken many years ago to establish a national roads system of which Australia could be proud. Unfortunately, in real terms, under the Fraser Government, there has been a steady reduction in Commonwealth spending on roads. The Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) stated earlier this year, in replying to the Labor shadow Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, that in the five years to 1980-81 there had been, in real terms, a reduction of $517m in Commonwealth road grants to the States. The Minister's answer revealed that in Queensland, the State that I represent, the loss over the period amounted to $ 95m. The expenditure of an additional $95m would not have solved the road problems of Queensland but it would have gone a long way towards alleviating some of the urgent problems that the State faces.

One aspect of funding for the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program which must not pass unnoticed is that many users of diesel fuel will be contributing towards the program though their industries are not related to transport. Bakers, brickworks and off-shore tourist resorts will all contribute one cent a litre, and two cents a litre next year, to the road program. Perhaps the most ironic of all the requirements is for State railways to pay the levy on diesel fuel and so contribute towards road construction. Because of the immense loads that diesel engines haul they use a tremendous amount of fuel. A passenger train like Queensland's 'Sunlander' uses one litre of fuel for every 250 metres that it travels-four litres a kilometre. Some of the long coal trains in Queensland have a tremendous thirst. They consume a litre for every 50 metres travelled-about 20 litres a kilometre.

All that fuel attracts an excise of 6.155c a litre whereas it did not attract any excise prior to the August Budget. That 6.155c includes one cent a litre for road funding and next year that will be increased to two cents a litre. I would have thought that assistance to rail authorities would ease the burden of road construction and maintenance. Surely if rail freights are more competitive then heavy freight will be carried more by rail than by road. The policy of requiring rail authorities to pay the fuel levy, as well as the total excise where no excise was previously payable, seems to be a deliberate attempt to reduce the competitiveness of the rail authorities, and thus put more emphasis on road freight and therefore a greater need for road construction and maintenance.

I draw the Senate's attention to that part of clause 23 of the Bill which states that tenders must be called for roadworks funded under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. I express some concern about the effects that tendering is having on employment in country areas and in particular on small country towns. I have spoken to workmen in rural areas who have been dismissed and to others who have been threatened with dismissal because local authorities cannot compete with private contractors. I fully understand the difficulties in coming to policy decisions about the need or otherwise to tender . However, the social consequences of these policy decisions must be carefully examined because where no alternative work is available the effect on rural workers who lose their livelihood and on the small community in which they live is simply devastating. Finally, I make some comments about Queensland's roads. I made some comments last week but I would like now to follow them up. The Minister for Transport and Construction, Mr Hunt, in his second reading speech on the Bill in the House of Representatives indicated that earlier this year he undertook an inspection of the Bruce Highway between Rockhampton and Townsville. He reported on that inspection as follows:
. . . the condition of the road was, to put it mildly, totally inadequate for a national highway which was serving an area undergoing such rapid development.

The Minister's comments were certainly mild compared to those of some people who have used the same section of the Bruce Highway and of those many people who have to use it regularly. It is a pity that Mr Hunt did not motor past Townsville. His comments then may not have been so mild. North Queensland residents do expect that their roads will be upgraded and they are looking for substantial funds from the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund for that purpose. Along with other senators from Queensland and Queensland members of the House of Representatives, I will be examining with great interest the details of the funds allocated for that part of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill. In the interests of the Senate's rising this week I have severely abridged the speech I had prepared . This is a particularly important piece of legislation for Queensland. The Bill is probably one of the most constructive and refreshingly innovative that we have seen before this chamber for some time. Simply, it will give us better roads sooner. I hope that the Government can see its way clear to accelerate the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program so that the work we are going to do and the roads we are going to build under it, can be advanced to provide a benefit to employment now, when it is needed, and all the spin-offs that will come from that. Although the days of unskilled labour and building roads with picks and shovels are no longer with us, accelerating this program will have an effect on the unemployment figures in this country. Also, it will put the country in a more competitive position by lowering our costs of production. Transport is a large component of the production costs of Australia. It is a vast country and surface transport is the predominant way of moving. It is an inherent part of our way of life. All the public transport programs in urban areas have failed because people have failed to recognise the inherent part that cars have in the Australian way of life.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from New South Wales and Victoria-I suppose that even there the roads could be better, in the best of all possible worlds-the roads in Australia are poor. I have thought for many years about the desirability of introducing toll roads in this country. I first used them 18 years ago in the United States of America and I am impressed with the concept. In a sense we will have a toll here . The figure of $35 a year that Senator Colston brought up is in a sense a toll that we will pay for the accelerated production of roads. An amount of $35 is a miniscule cost for the enormous benefits we will get. I do not agree with Senator Colston that $35 is much of an impost because the true cost of running any car is probably well over $1,000 or $2,000 a year. Very few people appreciate what it costs to keep a car on the road. These funds provided by this Bill will be additional and separate from the $3.65 billion provided under the existing funding program, and together they will provide $914m in 1982-83 and $1 ,208m in 1983-84. That contribution will have a significant effect on the rate of road construction.

One of the important parts of this Bill is the caveat that the States will be compelled to maintain their ratio of fundings. If they fall fack on what they are spending at present, then the benefit that they achieve under the Bicentennial funding program will be curtailed in the following year. Certainly in my own State, under the Minister for Main Roads, we have seen in the past a reduction in State funding as Commonwealth funding has increased. The State has then got stuck into the Commonwealth and attacked it for not spending as much money on roads in Queensland. That is quite incorrect. As Senator Colston said, we have no less an authority than the Federal Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) saying that the Bruce Highway between Rockhampton and Townsville is the worst national highway in Australia. That has to be related to the importance of the north and the large number of people who live up there. It is important for trade in Australia and indirectly because Queensland has the greatest length of national roads-something like 24.45 per cent of Australia's national roads-which have to be maintained and expanded.

The benefits that will come from this program are many. The one that is predominant is that of safety. Quite some years ago the United States highway trust funds were set up to build 42,000 miles of road and it was found that, as a result of that highways trust funding road construction, there were significant savings in the accident rate and in human lives. The cost of road deaths is appalling. In Queensland in 1980-81, 594 people were killed and over 9 ,000 people injured. In 1981-82 we had 609 killed. The cost of road accidents cannot fully be measured, but in looking after injured people and in the damage caused it is probably in excess of $3 billion a year. We have to remember that 92 per cent of all ground traffic in Australia is in cars, and those cars use roads, but apart from the human suffering, we have a cost on our cost of production, and 25 per cent is estimated to be the on-cost to the movement of goods in Australia because of qualitative defects in the road systems, the delays occasioned by the poor roads and the cost of repairs-unnecessary repairs- to the transport vehicles by using those roads.

Where will this money go in Queensland? What are our prime requirements? The first priority is to get some all-weather roads. The Bruce Highway is not an all -weather road. It passes through areas which are subjected to high rainfalls, flooding cyclonic rains, and it is absolutely essential that the great centres such as Cairns, Townsville, Mackay and Rockhampton have access to the rest of Australia by all-weather roads. Many of those roads are poorly engineered. They were built originally as cheaply as they could be built, and they follow the line of least resistance, often up valleys, and they have low bridges over creeks which frequently go under in any sort of flood rains at all-but even storms will put some of those bridges under. The other defect of the bridges in that area is that they are often one-way bridges. It is a particularly fatal form of Russian roulette, even though they have a 'give way' sign on them on one side, when southern tourists and semi-trailers battle it out with the locals as to who should have the right of way on a bridge. The consequences of that are nearly always tragically fatal.

So our requirement is to raise the level of the roads in a physical sense, to get them above flood levels and to get some wider and higher bridges so that they are not innundated after the first downpour. We certainly want to improve the location and alignments of roads and we certainly need wider sealed surfaces . Many of those roads are far too narrow. The roads being narrow, the shoulders break down, particularly at times of high rainfall and we end up with a narrower ribbon of bitumen, which again has inherent safety problems. I do not see why road engineers cannot build roads, even if they are going to build them narrow, with a flush concrete edging like a kerbing on a gutter that is sunk into the road so that the bitumen cannot break down and cannot spread. I do not see why bitumen cannot be supported by 6 inches or 12 inches of concrete going down maybe 12 inches to 18 inches into the road surface. That would contain the bitumen and stop it breaking up in times of bad weather.

In a general sense, our last requirement is for more bypasses on the Bruce Highway. Nambour is a classic example where the whole of the traffic from the north has to go down a steep hill, on a narrow road through the centre of a very busy country town. Apart from physical benefits, there will be enormous benefits socially. Australia is a large country. Communication between the people in various parts of it is important from a social point of view. There will be benefits in the reduction of fuel expenditure because time will be saved and there will be savings in the cost of repairs.

Finally, the Bill provides that the work will be done by tender. Senator Colston and Senator Bjelke-Petersen have spoken against the tender system. I am very firmly in favour of the way in which the Commonwealth Government, for some years now, has said that for national highways construction work will go to public tender. In no sense does that deny a local authority the right to tender. But as the members of this Parliament disbursing public funds we have an obligation upon us to get the maximum value for each dollar that we spend. The simple fact of life is that if we do work by tender we get twice the length of roads built as we do if we put the work to an in-house deal with the local authority. The Australian Labor Party and the National Party of Queensland have a vested interest-it is perfectly legitimate; it is just party politics-in supporting the local authorities there, because many of their professional politicians come up through shire and city council ranks. It is important there from a vote getting point of view, particularly in smaller towns and hamlets, to have a road maintenance crew of maybe 20 or 120 men living in a town who are dependent on the local authority for their work. That is just a fact of political life.

I am very conscious of the social consequences raised by Senator Colston that if the local authority does not get the road construction work those men do not have employment and, therefore, their position cannot be maintained by the council. It is not a loss of maybe 20 jobs but a loss of maybe 20 times three, when their families are included. In a small country town it can be a very significant factor if those people leave. But there are two answers to that. The first is that if a local authority, knowing the area, cannot compete with a contractor who probably comes from 500 or 1,000 miles away and who has no knowledge of local conditions then, bluntly, that authority should not be in the business and the public purse should not be supporting it. The second thing is that if the social consequences are so severe that no other employment can be found for these employees, the correct thing to do is to pay a subsidy directly to the shire or city council involved. Let us support people openly by direct subsidy so that we know what it costs. Let us not do it indirectly by giving them work on specious economic grounds, where the true cost of supporting those people is hidden and not known.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party, whilst giving support to the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill 1982, is cognisant of its many shortcomings. To that extent, we have moved a second reading amendment to the Bill, as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ', but the Senate-

(a) recognises the special roads needs of the various regions of Australia and deplores the failure of the Government to make provision in the Bill for an equitable allocation of national roads funds between the States and the Northern Territory; and
(b) condemns the Government for its discriminatory decision to allocate an inadequate level of funds to local government bodies for local roads'.

In case senators on the Government side think that our amendment is moved just for political purposes, let me say that the second reading speech of the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) gives credence to our amendment, because on page 3 of his speech he said that the Commonwealth acknowledges that the level of its funding of roads in recent years has not kept pace with increases in road construction costs. We in the Australian Labor Party are well aware of that too. That is the reason we have moved the amendment. I hope that it will be carried.

I should like to give a brief history of road funding going back over the last seven years. Between 1975-76 and 1980-81 the Fraser Government slashed real federal funding for roads by $517m. The effective cutbacks in each of the States was as follows: New South Wales, $92m; Queensland, $95m; my own State of South Australia, $77m; Victoria, $112m; Western Australia, $111m; and Tasmania, $30m. In the same period, annual Federal fuel taxation revenue more than quadrupled. The Commonwealth cut its share of total road funding by 20 per cent between 1975 -76 and 1979-80. To compensate for this, the States' share rose by 28 per cent over the same period. That means that States had to find more money out of their general revenue to maintain their road programs. Local government, likewise, has been severely hit by reduced Federal road funding. That is borne out, again, by the figures given by the Minister in his second reading speech to which I shall refer later if I have time; like the previous speakers, I have had to cut my remarks short.

Currently about 19 per cent of total Federal revenue from fuel taxation is directed to road works. This includes expenditure under the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. The paucity of Federal road funds forced the States and local government to direct an increasing share of available funds away from new construction to maintenance works. Full Federal responsibility for national highways was first established by the Labor Government in 1974. We are very proud of that achievement. Last year the Fraser Government abolished the discretionary power of State road authorities to determine which national road projects would be constructed by their own authorities and which should go out to tender. This has caused a substantial job loss from State road authorities, particularly from country depots, reduced roadworks carried out by local government bodies, created inflexibility and long delays in projects and increased paper work and supervision costs as well as forcing up the costs of many works. When one talks to local government authorities, particularly to council clerks, my words are well borne out. Unfortunately the tendering procedure has been extended to cover urban and rural arterial roads and urban public transport projects funded under the ABRD program. The compulsory tendering procedure will be reviewed when the Labor Party returns to Government because we feel a lot of anomalies exist in this compulsory tendering system under which we now operate.

Federal road funds for arterial and local roads are allocated to the States under the provisions of the Roads Grants Act 1982. In 1982-83, $734m is being provided with $778m in 1983-84 and $825m in 1984-85. The amounts represent increases in cash terms of 7 per cent, 6 per cent and 6 per cent respectively over the previous year's allocation, which are well below the current rate of road construction cost increases of approximately 15 per cent. So we can see with those reductions in funding that our roads, rather than being built to a better standard, will be built to an inferior standard. These moneys will be supplemented by moneys from the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program , which is funded by the Bill we are discussing.

This program will provide $2,500m for roadwork between 1982-83 and 1987-88. It is being financed by a special tax on motor spirit and diesolene of one cent a litre, doubling to two cents a litre from 1 July next year. It is clear from advice from the New South Wales and Victorian Governments that the national highways projects being promised by the Fraser Government cannot be completed under the program unless the special tax is substantially increased or construction standards are reduced. Unfortunately under this legislation that will happen. In New South Wales alone there will be a shortfall of $1 billion. The Australian Automobile Association, representing 3.5 million motorists, has labelled the program a confidence trick. Many local government authorities are saying the same thing to me. The Association argues that it should be funded from existing federal taxation revenues rather than by the imposition of a further $2.5 billion tax on road users. It argues that the program should have been structured to ensure that heavy road vehicles provide a more realistic share of the cost of roadworks.

Local government has done badly under the ABRD program. If we look at the second reading speech of the Minister we see that funding has dropped from 15 per cent to 12 per cent under this ABRD legislation we are discussing today. The Australian Council of Local Government Associations had stated that local government will, in net terms, get a negligible increase in funds this year and a substantial reduction in real terms in 1984-85. Roadworks are an important source of jobs with about 64 per cent of direct and indirect expenditure going to the employment of labour. Local government employs about 34,000 people on roadworks in Australia. An expansion of federal funds for local roads would create additional jobs, expecially in country and regional areas. Goodness knows , we could well do with those jobs being created in South Australia at this time , particularly with the massive retrenchments that are going on in the south east of my State due to the downturn in the building industry and the importation of cheap timber from New Zealand.

A special local roads job development program to carry out local road construction and maintenance projects would reduce the backlog of local roads needs and create employment. That is something to which we will be giving great urgency when we assume the Treasury benches. A special supplementary provision of road funds could be allocated via the States to local government bodies based on the following criteria: Potential for the development of jobs, established road needs and energy and economic savings to be gained. Overall decisions would need to consider special regional needs of the area in which individual projects are located with final approval resting with the Australian Government. Incompatibility of Federal and State road classifications creates difficulty in providing federal funds to local government. Action is needed to achieve great uniformity in road classifications to ensure that federal funds intended for local roads are transmitted in full to local government. That accords with a decision taken at a meeting of the District Council of Murray Bridge last evening. Whilst the Council agrees with this legislation in principle the District Clerk today told me that the Council is of the opinion that more money should be made available to local government authorities so that the Council can get on with its local road programs.

Co-operative consultations between Federal, State and local governments are required to develop more effective arrangements. Differing fixed State charges on road users in respect of vehicle licensing and registration bear little relationship to actual use made of the vehicle concerned. Such charges could be replaced at the request of the States by a fuel levy designated by the States, collected by the Commonwealth and returned to the States in full. This would overcome the annual financial hurdle of registration and vehicle licensing charges for motorists. Such a pay-as-you-drive plan would benefit low income earners and pensioners who must operate a motor vehicle. A levy designated by the States would have to be equitable having regard to vehicle usage, and consultation with local government, road transport and motorist organisations would be necessary.

The Labor Party recently sat down for many hours and updated its road program which we will be putting to the people at the next election. I want to make brief reference to some of the things which we have embodied in our policy. Labor, in government, will accelerate construction of the national highway system. We will make grants to the States for the construction of other roads, bicycle paths and boat-loading ramps. We will initiate consultations with State and local governments to ensure that federal road grants for local government are passed on in full to their intended recipients. In consultation with local government, road transport and motorist organisations we will initiate discussions with the States to formulate agreement for the development of a national funding scheme to finance road construction and maintenance, replacing State motoring and road transport charges levied for this program. Subject to contemporary budgetary constraints we will establish a local roads job development program. Whilst we see every time we pick up a newspaper that the Fraser Government is pinching many of the Opposition's policies I would have no grouches at all if, having spelt out what we intend to do in government, the present Government immediately pinched some of the planks of that platform and implemented them, particularly the establishment of a local road job development program.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you intend to fund it?

—The honourable senator asks: 'How do we intend to fund it'? We could recoup a lot of this tax which is not being paid, Senator. The Government should get on with the job and recoup that unpaid tax which tax evaders are ripping off from the Treasury. The Government should do something beneficial with it. The Government could create jobs. The people who want to work instead of being on the dole and being a burden on the Treasury-not because they want to but because of the Government's policies-in turn will become PAYE taxpayers who would have to pay their tax. There is no way a man in the work force in this country can evade tax. The low income earners pay their tax. The very high income earners, as the honourable senator would know have all the loopholes in the world open to them to evade tax. The Government may ask where this money will come from for the job creation program. It will be returned by way of taxation in one instance. It will also be returned by way of extra taxation paid by small businesses which provide the materials to carry out these works. I could go through the whole ambit of job creation. Instead of paying out money to people who do not have jobs the Commonwealth Government could get some money back into revenue by way of taxation from people who would be employed. I could go on for the rest of my 17 minutes and take issue with Senator Messner, but because of the time restraints-
—What?

—I could talk about where the money comes from. I could look at the honourable senator for the whole of my 17 minutes and give him a perfect illustration of what the Government ought to be doing in an effort to create jobs in this country. While some people say there are others about who would not work if a job was put in front of them, only a very small minority is involved. Most people want to work and maintain their credibility in the community. I hope that in the not too distant future many of the things that I have outlined here today and which are Labor Party policy will be implemented when we are in Government. As I say, the Opposition, whilst supporting this Bill in principle, is moving that amendment. I hope that the Senate will agree with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill 1982 is a most significant piece of legislation which provides for a six-year program at a cost of $2,500m for the upgrading of the Australian road system. It represents not only an upgrading program for roads but also a commitment by the Government to Australia's future economic development. At the outset, it is interesting to draw attention to the main benefits of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program. The main benefit accruing from this program will be a major transformation of the Australian road network which will result in improved safety on Australia's roads, improved communication between the States through better arterial roads as well as national highways, additional direct employment for more than 8,000 people in the road construction industry and a grand total of 20,000 jobs both directly and indirectly as a result of the program in its duration.

SPEECH.PARA: I will highlight some of the effects that this program has on South Australia. Under the scheme, South Australia will receive 7.2 per cent of the total funds made available. In real terms, this figure of 7.2 per cent will result in $12.9m and $30.7m being made available for road works in South Australia during the 1982-83 and 1983-84 financial years respectively. When debating this legislation in the other place, my colleague the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) used some interesting figures to demonstrate that South Australia will not receive its rightful share of funds under this scheme. Mr Hall pointed out that, although South Australia consumes 9.34 per cent of total Australian fuel consumption, it will receive only 7.2 per cent of the funds to be made available under this program. It needs to be remembered that this program is to be paid by way of a fuel levy. It seems to me that South Australia is missing out.
The Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) disputed Mr Hall's figures and suggested that the consumption in that State was actually about 7.9 per cent. He said:

Under this program the South Australian share will be 7.2 per cent. If those figures are right, there is not a great disparity between what the consumption of fuel will be and the allocation to South Australia.

I differ with the Minister in this respect. South Australia, regardless of the figures that one uses, is not getting its fair share of normal road grants or grants to be made under this scheme. South Australia has had a fall-off in the percentage of road grants that it receives. This has been noticeable over the last 10 years. This fall-off has been to the benefit of States such as Queensland and Western Australia. In 1971-72, South Australia received 11.62 per cent of total grants. That was done, of course, under the previous scheme which had regard to population and area as the parameters under which the grants were made. But from the level of 11.62 per cent in 1971-72 the level of general road grants has now dropped to 8.22 per cent. The South Australian proportion fell in 1974 because of the enactment of the National Roads Act and the Roads Grants Act which were introduced by the Whitlam Government. It should be pointed out that South Australia has 9 per cent of the Australian population, 15.5 per cent of the area, 12.2 per cent of road length, 9.42 per cent of vehicles and 9.21 per cent of vehicle kilometres travelled.

I refer again to the speech made by the honourable member for Boothby. It should be noted that, as a former Premier of South Australia, he has an insight into the distribution of money among the three tiers of government in Australia. On 20 October, he said:

South Australia, under this proposal will get 6.5 per cent of the bicentennial funds for national roads whilst it has 16 per cent of the national road lengths within its borders. We will get 7.6 per cent of funds for urban arterial roads whilst we have 9.25 per cent of arterial roads. For rural arterial roads we will get 7.5 per cent of the funds whilst we have 10.25 per cent of the national total within our border.

I believe that the Minister and the Government need to address themselves to the question of equity, that is, we must ensure that the fairest possible distribution of these moneys occurs between the States. South Australia's percentage drop has been to the benefit of Queensland and Western Australia which have received a greater share of road grants. It is argued quite often by defenders of this state of affairs that these States are developing States that are carrying the other States because of the development that is taking place and that, therefore, they are rightly entitled to a greater share of the road grant funds. I do not agree with that argument. We are living in a federal system, supposedly a system of co-operation for the good of the Commonwealth. The fact that Queensland and Western Australia are economically healthier than South Australia should, I believe, strengthen the case that South Australia is entitled to a greater share of the funds.

According to figures supplied by the Minister, the total road grants-that is, normal grants and grants to be made under this program that we are now discussing-will rise by 30 per cent in South Australia, 35.3 per cent in Queensland and 34 per cent in Western Australia during this financial year. That seems fair enough, but when we look at the 1983-84 situation, the increases over the 1981-82 Budget figures will be 80.8 per cent in Queensland, 76.7 per cent in Western Australia and 68.1 per cent in South Australia. That seems to indicate that there is an inequity with respect to the allocation of these funds. These are matters that must be addressed by the Minister. He has the ability to remedy any inequity that arises by adjusting grants made under the Roads Grants Act. I hope that a willingness to do so will be apparent in the future.

I turn to the matter of local roads. I have been involved as Secretary of the Canberra committee on local government, in detailed discussions with the Australian Council of Local Government Associations and, less formally, in discussions with the South Australian Local Government Association. Both of those organisations are pleased with the principle of this program. However, concern has been expressed that, in relative terms, local roads have been downgraded under the program. National and arterial road categories have been boosted or at least maintained. The ACLGA believes that, viewed as part of the total program-that is, the bicentennial program, the lifting of the local government diesel fuel exemption and the fact that local government will have to pay a surcharge that will finance this scheme-as Senator McLaren said, local government will be only slightly better off as a result of this initiative. The Local Government Associations admit that overall there will be a marginal gain this year and a two to three per cent increase in real terms next year, but in the third year no growth at all will be recorded.

This third year situation has recently been the subject of discussion between the Minister and the ACLGA, which has pointed out that there will be a reduction of eight to nine per cent in real terms in that year. As I understand it, the Minister has accepted those figures and has given an undertaking to look at ways in which that situation might be avoided. I understand that local government will benefit, indirectly or directly, as a result of the legislation dealing with a wages pause that is being debated in the House of Representatives. With $ 300m-odd being made available for capital works, I hope that local government will share more equitably in those funds than it has done in the past. I believe that local roads and local government deserve the support of this Government. I believe that local roads must be regarded as just as important to local government as the national and arterial roads systems are to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. It is an important one. It touches on a very important area of government initiative at this time. I shall mention just a few of the matters that were raised by individual senators during the debate. Senator Gietzelt moved an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Bill. The amendment, firstly, seeks to have the Bill make provision for the apportioning of national roads funds between the States and the Northern Territory in order to address the special road needs of the various regions of Australia. It is important to recognise that the very reason the Bill provides flexibility in the allocation of national roads funds is the Government's desire to meet the differing needs of the various States and the Northern Territory in that important area.

SPEECH.PARA: Although the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) has advised States of indicative allocations for the first two years of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program, it is not possible to finalise the distribution of funds for national roads between the States and the Territory to meet our national objectives until firm works programs have been developed. As honourable senators will no doubt be aware, the Commonwealth's major priority in the national roads area is to bring the declared national highways system in all States and the Northern Territory to a dust-free, virtually flood-free standard by the bicentennial year, 1988. It is the Government's intention that no State will be advantaged at the expense of another in the standard to which its segment of the national highway system will be upgraded. Allocations under the ABRD Program will reflect the works required in each State to achieve that overall objective.

Secondly, Senator Gietzelt's amendment indicates the Opposition's concern about the adequacy of the level of funds to be made available to local government for local roads. Let me assure the honourable senator that the Government needs no persuasion about the importance of local roads in facilitating travel and assisting the development of economic and social activities within local communities. The Government, therefore, paid particular attention to ensure that local government would not be disadvantaged in the allocation of ABRD funds. In 1982-83, the total allocation for local roads under the ABRD Program and the road grants program is estimated to be about $200m, an increase of some $39m or 24 per cent over 1981-82. This is a substantial increase which will more than offset the additional excise charges on local authorities, which are unlikely to exceed about $10m in 1982-83. Benefits to local government will be sustained in 1983-84 when total allocations to local roads will be an estimated $235m, which is $73m or 46 per cent higher than the 1981-82 level.

Senator McLaren stated that there had been a decrease of some $517m in the amount of funds going to the States for road grants over seven years of Fraser governments. Perhaps Senator McLaren needs it to be pointed out again-I know that we have done so on many occasions-that in fact local government has been served very well by the share of personal income tax which has gone to it under Fraser Government policies since 1976. An amount of $1,787.8m has gone to local government over that period. If there has been a fall-off as a result of decreased funds going to the States, it has been more than truly offset by the advantages to local government of its being able to choose its own way of spending the extra funds coming to it from the Federal Government's revenue resource.

During the debate Senator Haines proposed a further amendment to the second reading motion. This amendment concerns the assessment of environmental consequences of road works and the provision of rest areas with appropriate vegetation along our roads. I should make it quite clear that the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 and section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act apply to road projects which utilise Commonwealth funds. Under the existing road grants program, it is required that State Ministers provide the Minister for Transport and Construction with a State environmental clearance for all road works proposed for Commonwealth funding. Furthermore, projects in environmentally sensitive areas can also be reviewed at the Commonwealth level. Agreed arrangements exist between the Commonwealth and the States whereby the submission of environmental impact statements can be required . These same arrangements will apply under the ABRD Program. Roadside rest areas are eligible for Commonwealth assistance where they form an adjunct to the road network. Such rest areas are usually landscaped where appropriate. I would hope for those reasons that Senator Haines will see fit not to pursue her amendment.

Criticism was made by some honourable senators of the Government's record in the funding of roads. While the Government acknowledges that the level of its funding of roads in recent years has not kept pace fully with increases in road construction costs, funds to be provided over the next two years under the ABRD Program and road grants programs are well in excess of recent movements in road building costs. Total Commonwealth road funding in 1982-83 will now be about $ 914m. This represents an increase of 33 per cent when compared with road funds allocated in 1981-82. For 1983-84, Commonwealth expenditure will total an estimated $1,208m, which represents a 76 per cent increase over 1981-82. These are very substantial increases and reflect the Government's determination to bring about a major improvement in the Australian road network over the next six years.

I should explain to honourable senators that it is with this objective in mind that the Government has seen fit to require the States to maintain their own level of road funding in real terms. If the benefits of the ABRD Program are to be maximised, it will be necessary to ensure that Commonwealth funds are not used by the States for simply substituting funding which they would otherwise have provided. I can well appreciate the concern that has been expressed about the possible inflationary effect of the surcharge. However, all the evidence suggests that this impact will be minimal. Even the 2c per litre increase in fuel costs over two years will lead to an estimated increase in the consumer price index of less than one-half of a percentage point. For the average motorist travelling 15,000 kilometres a year, this will involve the payment of 67c extra per week.

During the debate Senator Bjelke-Petersen expressed concern about the requirement that some ABRD Projects must be put out to tender. The Government believes that the tendering requirement for national roads and arterial roads will create a competitive environment for the implementation of the major construction works to be undertaken under the ABRD Program. This will ensure that maximum value is obtained for each dollar invested in these road works. The Government believes that the taxpayers of this country deserve nothing less than maximum efficiency for government expenditure.

I should mention here, too, the most important consequence of the ABRD Program; that is, its favourable impact on employment. Of course, the longer the passage of this legislation is delayed, the less likely it is that we will be able to get jobs created and started quickly because expenditure does rely upon the passage of this legislation. I am pleased to note that this aspect has been recognised, however, by several honourable senators in the course of the debate. The ABRD Program will provide employment for a further 8,000 persons in a road construction industry, with a total of some 20,000 jobs in both indirect and direct employment generated thereby. The additional 8,000 road jobs represent a significant increase of some 10 per cent in road construction employment. Most of these jobs will be located in the private sector as a result of the tendering requirements contained in the Bill. Almost two-thirds of those jobs will be in rural areas.

The question of relative State shares of Commonwealth funding is, of course, a most vexing one. It was raised here today by my colleague from South Australia, Senator Jessop. Each State can identify particular economic, social or geographical factors which have an impact on its road needs. In that regard, Senator Crichton-Browne in particular presented a well argued case in respect of national highways in Western Australia. Similar issues were also raised in other States. The overall objective of the ABRD Program is to accelerate the upgrading of roads in all the States and the Northern Territory. In particular, our entire national highway system will be upgraded to a high standard by 1988. As I mentioned earlier, the allocations to be provided under the ABRD Program for national roads reflect that goal. Allocations for other road categories preserve the corresponding funding relativities which apply under the Roads Grants Act. These were established in 1977-78 on the basis of funding recommendations put forward by the former Bureau of Roads. Arguments about the States' shares will no doubt continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this would be a suitable time to indicate to the Committee that the Government does not agree with the amendment put forward by Senator Evans. I will not delay the Committee at length because Senator Missen has already put down some of the points I wished to put down in reply to Senator Evans. Since those points riled Senator Evans last time there is no point in doing it again. I adopt the arguments put forward by Senator Missen when the Committee last considered this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government regards this amendment as a significant amendment. It believes it would significantly weaken the proposed National Crimes Commission. The Government appreciates the sort of argument put forward by the shadow Attorney- General but its concern is that experience, in particular the experience of the United States of America, tells us that an attempt to state too precisely the limits of jurisdiction of a body such as this could well result in delay- producing disputes as to whether some particular investigation comes within the jurisdiction of the body.

We think the directions given to the Commission under clause 7 are clear in establishing the general ambit of the Commission's inquiry. We do not believe that it is productive to hand to a litigious person who may be both very wealthy and involved in organised crime, legal weapons which may well enable delaying tactics to be pursued when the Commission is conducting its investigations. We think the proposal, and in particular the deletion of the opening words of sub- clause 2, would mean that any activity by the Commission would be subject to challenge in the courts on the grounds that the matters looked into by the Commission are not offences as defined in clause 7 (2). So we think a ready weapon is being made available here for those who wish to see an ineffective Commission.

The concern expressed by Senator Evans is basically a concern based on civil liberties. We see that concern as being exaggerated and, in any event, point to the short life of five years proposed for the Commission which will give us experience of its actual operation. The requirement of the proposed section is, I think, quite clear. I do not believe that the amendment put forward by the Opposition is necessary. We do not want to be in a position where there is virtually an invitation to conduct challenges in the courts to the carrying out of particular investigations by the Commission on grounds that the offences in question do not satisfy the definition in clause 7 (2).

If the Senate is minded to alter and narrow this clause then, in the view of the Government, it would be preferable to see it narrowed by the removal of clause 7 (2) (d). I do not advocate that but I think that if there is concern in the Senate as to the width of the types of offences about which the Commission might be concerned it would be less damaging to the operation of the National Crimes Commission if clause 7 (2) were removed and the opening words of clause 7 (2) remained. The Government opposes the amendment proposed to sub-clause (2) and will vote against it.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Australian Democrats will not support the Australian Labor Party's amendment, but we will seek to move an amendment to clause 7 sub-clause (2) (d). SPEECH.PARA: Any circumstance suggesting that an offence may have been, or may be being, committed against a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The supposed civil libertarians in this place are long going to have clause 7 of the National Crimes Commission Bill on their conscience if they follow the course which Senator Missen mapped out in supporting the Government on this and which has now at the very last minute been determined to be followed, it appears, by the Australian Democrats. The net result of the contributions we have heard from the Democrats' spokesman, Senator Macklin, and Senator Missen are to give carte blanche to the new National Crimes Commission to do anything it wants in relation to any kind of matter at all that occurs to it. There is simply no jurisdictional limitation whatsoever cast upon the Crimes Commission so far as clause 7 remains significantly unamended.

SPEECH.PARA: The point about sub-clause (2) at the moment is that it is simply, as I said at some length the last time we met, exhortatory in its character. It has no legal effect whatever. Sub-clause (2) states that the Commission shall seek, so far as practicable, to direct its activities in relation to particular defined areas. It does not say that the Commission must confine its activities to those areas. It does not define, as the Australian Labor Party amendment would seek to do, offences in terms of those areas. As such it has some use as a statement of legislative intent as to how the power should be exercised but, for all its practical utility, it is no more than a joke. It is of no legal force or effect whatsoever. If paragraph (d) is left in sub-clause (2) it is a bad joke because the reach of (2) (d) is such as to completely negate, one would have thought, the potentially restrictive effect of paragraphs (a), (b) and (c). To that extent I agree that it would be desirable to remove (d) from it.

But even if (d) is removed from sub-clause (2), as it is presently cast, that whole sub-clause is still a joke. It only ceases to become a joke if sub-clause (2) is taken away from its present format and is made actually part of the definition of an offence-that is, of course, exactly what the ALP's amendment is seeking to do-so that there will be some formal legal constraint, not just an exhortatory restraint, on what the Commission can do. That has to be appreciated as the first point. The Opposition is not being met half way simply by getting rid of the extraordinarily wide, lunaticly wide, paragraph (d). This does not meet the Opposition's point at all. The whole point and thrust of the Opposition 's amendment is to set some legal jurisdictional constraints on what the Commission can actually do.

The only answers we have heard as to why that is a bad idea were from Senator Macklin and Senator Chaney. Senator Macklin said that these provisions do not impose any constraints at all on what the Commission could do if they were part of its jurisdictional limitations. Senator Chaney said that they pose excessive restrictions because they will open up the possibility of formal legal challenges being made by all sorts of shady customers who will seek to use these provisions to grind to a halt the proceedings of the Commission. I simply say in that respect-I do not want to repeat at great length what I said last time-that to write the amendment in the way proposed by the Opposition and to formally limit the jurisdiction by reference to the descriptions of offences set out in paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) would not be to unduly restrict or limit the scope of the Commission's operations in such a way as to allow the Commission to be hamstrung by a series of jurisdictional challenges of one kind or another.

As an example I use a kind of geographical analogy. At the moment the jurisdiction of the Commission is totally unfettered in any way, shape of form. There are no practical limitations. Geographically one might say that it is the size of the city of Melbourne. It is almost completely open-ended. If we do as the Opposition would say and actually write in paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) as part of the definition of offences so that the Commission has to confine itself to offences which are in the nature of organised criminal activity or involve the use of sophisticated methods or elements of corruption we would, as it were, reduce the scope of the Commission's activities to something like-using the Melbourne analogy-the size of the Melbourne Cricket Ground. There is still a very large area in which to play. It would be possible to define further in a very narrow way the jurisdiction of the Commission with some very tight restrictions such that it would not be the same size as the MCG but about the size of a cricket pitch on the MCG.

Under those circumstances, if there is only a very narrowly prescribed area within which the Commission can operate, one can imagine a whole series of jurisdictional challenges slowing down, disrupting and hamstringing what the Commission is about. We are saying that the language contained in (a), (b) and ( c) is not so narrowly constraining as to hamstringing the Commission, but it does at least set some parameters, some boundaries, within which the Commission can operate, which boundaries are simply not there the way the clause is cast at the moment. I can do no more than repeat myself endlessly if I go over this track so I will sit down and leave the matter at that. I hope that there will be some reconsideration by the Democrats whose abdication of responsibility on this matter at the last moment does seem to me to be rather alarming.

Clause 14 (Search warrants).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 7, clause 14, sub-clause (5), leave out the sub-clause.

This clause is about search warrants. Sub-clause (5) not only enables the person executing a warrant on behalf of the National Crimes Commission to search for and seize objects which are within the scope of that warrant but also enables the person executing the warrant, if he finds-and the nub of the problem is in paragraph (b)-'anything that he beleives on reasonable grounds to be connected with another matter into which the Commission is conducting an investigation', to seize that thing provided there is reasonable grounds to believe that its seizure then and there is necessary to ensure that it is not lost or destroyed.

We would argue that this provision goes much further than is either necessary or desirable to ensure that the Commission does in fact obtain documentary and other evidence that is relevant to the way in which it needs to go about its business. We say that particularly because the language, it will be appreciated, is a reference to not simply evidence being seen which is relevant to the commission of some offence but rather to material being seen which is believed to be connected with 'another matter' into which the Commission is conducting an investigation. That means that since, as we have already established, under the Commission's jurisdiction by virtue of clause 7 it can of its own motion investigate more or less anything it wants to, we have through the vehicle of this clause an open-ended mandate for the Commission, or those acting on its behalf, in effect to seize anything that it seems a good idea at the time to grab.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is more than that. It is where concealment, loss mutilation or destruction might occur.

—That is a condition subsequent. If they see it and think that it is connected with some other matter, however remote from the subject matter of the judicial warrant that they have obtained-if they think it might be useful for some other matter that has nothing to do with the warrant just issued-they may then grab it provided that, the condition subsequent, they believe that not to do so then and there would be to ensure its loss or destruction.

SPEECH.PARA: Several things need to be said about that. First, the Government has made the point that provisions of that kind are either not entirely unknown to the common law or-and there is argument about this-if that is not the case at least a provision of this kind is contained in the Government's own Criminal Investigation Bill 1981, which makes provision for someone in the course of executing a warrant that is issued in respect of one offence seizing material or property that he happens to see lying around and has reasonable grounds to believe to be connected with, or evidence of, some other offence.

True, that provision is contained in the 1981 Criminal Investigation Bill, although I hasten to add not its 1977 predecessor or the 1975 Bill drafted by the Law Reform Commission. The reason the clause in question was not contained in the 1975 Criminal Investigation Bill, or the 1977 version, is that it was preceived to be not only wrong in principle but also unnecessary. This takes me to the real nub of the objection to what is happening here. There is now provision in this Bill for a telephone application for a warrant. In the House of Representatives the particular amendment providing for application for a judicial warrant by the agency of a telephone was moved simultaneously with the amendment that I am moving today which seeks to delete the power to go on an open-ended search once one is inside premises and to seize things not within the ambit of the warrant. There is a logical connection between those two propositions. It may well be the case that one could envisage circumstances in which a person executing a warrant sees evidence of crucial importance in relation to some matter that is centrally relevant to the Commission's investigations and that he has grounds for believing may be destroyed if he does not pick it up there and then.

The solution that we adopted in regard to the amendments moved in the House of Representatives was to enable the executor of the warrant, under those circumstances, to make immediate application to a judge for a warrant to get the authority to seize those additional goods as well as additional materials which, by definition, were not in contemplation at the time the original warrant was issued. So there is a practical provision by way of the telephone warrant system now provided to cope with that unusual urgent circumstance in which there might conceivably be agreement that it is proper that the materials in question be sought.

What happened, of course, in the House of Representatives, in the time-honoured sort of double dealing to which one becomes used in this place with this Government, is that the provision for the obtaining of telephone warrants was accepted but the provision to delete the equivalent of sub-clause (5) of clause 14 was rejected. So the Government has had its cake and is eating it too. It has been given an additional procedure, that of the telephone warrant, designed specifically to cope with the removal of the particular power in this sub-clause but has kept the power in the sub-clause as well. In the view of the Opposition, one simply cannot have it both ways in this respect. Either there is a problem or there is not. Either the problem can be met by the use of telephone warrants or it cannot. If it can be, as the Government seems to believe by having accepted our amendment providing for telephone warrants, it is utterly unnecessary to have sub-clause (5) in its present form.

I finish where I started by saying that there is a difference. Even if honourable senators opposite are unmoved by all of that and say that, as a matter of common law or statutory reform, there ought to be a provision to cover the situation of an extended search beyond the scope of an original warrant in the case of police investigations of criminal offences, I ask them for goodness sake to appreciate that we are not here talking about matters that are as narrowly and precisely defined as are criminal offences. We are simply talking about matters into which the Commission is conducting an investigation-and as the Bill is drawn, the Commission can conduct an investigation into anything it pleases, so no private documents will be sacrosanct. No physical materials in any home or office will any longer be safe from the depredations of those who are in the business of executing Commission warrants. The scope of the jurisdiction of the Commission is so potentially enormous, and the scope of the power that is vested in those who are executing warrants is so wide, that we have contained in this clause, another absolutely outrageous interference with basic liberties, an interference which is utterly unnecessary given the availability of the telephone warrant system.

If Senator Missen can rationalise his way out of that, or members of the Australian Democrats can do so individually or collectively, I will be delighted to hear how they do it. They will have a great deal of difficulty in persuading me or anyone else in the community that they deserve serious regard as protectors of civil liberties if they are prepared to contemplate a clause of this kind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little surprised at some of the language used by Senator Evans in seeking to assert this amendment. He suggested that the Government's action in choosing to accept a Labor amendment and at the same time not accepting a related Labor amendment amounted to double dealing, which seemed a rather strange use of language. To suggest that the fact that we have now agreed to an amendment which gives the opportunity to apply for a warrant by telephone is a matter of having our cake and eating it too is erroneous. To the extent that we can add to the effectiveness of the National Crimes Commission by agreeing to Labor amendments, we will of course do so. But that puts us under no obligation to accept other amendments, whether related or not, and certainly does not involve double dealing in any normal sense of that term.

SPEECH.PARA: The provision makes quite clear that sub-clause (5) of clause 14 simply provides for the situation in which someone is searching in accordance with a warrant properly issued-not, of course, by the Commission itself but by a judicial officer-and comes across material of another kind that, on reasonable grounds, he believes to be connected with the matter being investigated by the Commission, or anything that he believes, on reasonable grounds, is connected with another matter into which the Commission is conducting an investigation. Provision is made for his seizing that also to prevent its loss, mutilation or destruction. That seems to me to be a very sensible provision. I do not think that many would expect someone investigating or seizing material under a search warrant, who comes across other relevant material which relates to matters properly within the purview of the Commission, to leave that material unattended .

It may well be that in come cases the provision which has been inserted at the suggestion of the opposition for the obtaining of the telephone warrant would be applicable and would enable the material to be seized and protected from loss or mutilation but, of course, one cannot guarantee either that a telephone would be available or that a judge would be at the other end of the telephone line at any given time. It seems to be but a partial remedy for a circumstance which may in practice arise.

I believe it is worth referring to the rules that apply under the general law relating to search warrants. In that regard, I quote Lord Denning who, in Ghani v. Jones, as reported in All England Law Reports at page 1703, pointed out:

I would start by considering the law where police officers enter a man's house by virtue of a warrant, or arrest a man lawfully, with or without a warrant, for a serious offence. I take it to be settled law, without citing cases, that the officers are entitled to take any goods which they find in his possession or in his house which they reasonably believe to be material evidence in relation to the crime for which he is arrested or for which they enter. If in the course of their search they come upon any other goods which show him to be implicated in some other crime, they may take them provided they act reasonably and detain them no longer than is necessary.

Then a number of cases are cited. It is having regard to that sort of approach and the dictates of common sense that the Government has put both in the Criminal Investigation Bill and in the National Crimes Commission Bill a provision for the possibility that the officer when executing a warrant might find things which are of a different kind to that specified in the warrant but which are relevant to matters before the Commission. I think it is a rather strange idea that because they are not specified in the warrant they should therefore be left when there is a possibility of destruction. There is the possibility within the clause itself that the officer must believe on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to seize the thing to prevent its concealment, loss or destruction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which limits it quite a bit.

—It does limit it; that is quite true. So we have this situation in regard to general law and also we have the example of the United States where we know that under its rules, however restrictive they might be, an officer who has lawfully entered to execute a warrant is permitted to take other relevant things. As a matter of common sense, as I said, as well as a matter of comparison with these jurisdictions, we believe that the provision in sub-clause (5) is a sensible and proper one and should not be deleted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The intent of the amendment moved by the Australian Labor Party can be agreed to. It is a matter about which in some areas one might have some concern, even in the area of State jurisdiction. However, the Australian Democrats will not support the Labor Party amendment. I believe it still leaves open a number of difficult areas that have not been picked up. Senator Evans has pointed out that the provision of being able to get a warrant by telephone would cover most cases. I believe that is correct.

—My emphasis is on quality, not quantity. The justification for this amendment can be explained as follows. Most of the concern about the operation of crimes commissions has tended to revolve around adverse publicity to witnesses who appear before them. With respect, I do not want to interrupt the loud conversations in the chamber--
—Well, make it interesting.
—Order!

—I shall make it interesting, by talking about one of the real concerns in relation to the operation of crimes commissions. It is about witnesses and others having their names dragged muddily through the operations of these commissions, about people being the target for scuttlebutt, about people having all sorts of unfounded and scurrilous allegations being made against them. Perhaps it is impossible in the context of any kind of royal commission or crimes commission inquiry to avoid altogether the possibility of people's reputations being put at risk by the kind of material that is put before such inquiries. It is in the nature of the beast that this sort of evidence, which would not satisfy normal court standards of admissibility, is put.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the nature of an inquisitorial proceeding. That is its justification, in many ways-that it enables a freewheeling, far-ranging investigation to take place. But there are real difficulties, of course, again in terms of civil liberties and the reputations of individuals, if that occurs. The member for Melbourne Ports, Clyde Holding, in the other place, gave a rather moving account of some of the difficulties that he personally had experienced in relation to royal commissions, with his name being dragged through the mud and the subsequent clearance of his name being given far less publicity. The question is : What on earth can we do about that?

One solution is to ensure that all proceedings of the National Crimes Commission are held in private, with no public access by the media or anyone else who might be minded to report the scuttlebutt, the scurrilous allegations and so on. That solution is not an altogether unwelcome one to the Opposition. We note the way in which the Bill has been amended already in the House of Representatives to widen the scope of the powers of the Commission to hold hearings in camera and in effect, particularly where people's reputations are involved, the power is there for the Commission to order that the evidence not be published and to hold the whole proceeding in camera. That is not a totally satisfactory solution to the problem because where in camera proceedings are held they cannot, by definition, be the subject of scrutiny by outsiders. One of the problems in relation to royal commissions and the contemplated Crimes Commission here is the fear that very many people hold that they will not be democratically or justly operating bodies, that they will operate like star chambers, and to the extent that they operate behind closed doors that will give credence to that kind of concern.

So the next step to which one is led in contemplating the problem and the possible solutions to it is to say that one ought, then, to impose perhaps some limitations on the extent to which Crimes Commission proceedings can be reported . One kind of restriction would be to allow people there physically but to set absolute limits on what could be reported. That does not seem to be entirely satisfactory, for the reason that if people are to be there at all the real utility of their being there, to ensure that the proceedings are kept fair in the way in which they operate, is that they can tell the world about it if the proceedings are not fair. So an absolute blanket prohibition on reporting by people who are physically present does not seem to be terribly satisfactory.

Another solution which I have canvassed from time to time on behalf of the Opposition is to set a limitation on what can be reported by saying, for example , that the only evidence which can be the subject of reporting would be that evidence which can satisfy ordinary standards of admissibility in the courts. The kind of evidence, be it hearsay or otherwise, which would be admissible in the courts but is admissible in royal commission proceedings, would not be able to be reported; but ordinary factual hard evidence, relevant and direct, which would be admissible in the courts, could be the subject of publicity in the ordinary way. That might solve most of the practical problems with scuttlebutt and unfounded hearsay allegations. But there are enormous and obvious practical difficulties about making any such system work. There would have to be some process of certification, either on application or at the end of each day, by the commissioner as to what did and did not satisfy the criteria of admissibility, and it would be undoubtedly make the practical operation of proceedings very complex.

That, really, is what brings us back to the proposal contained in the amendment . This is a proposal which says: 'Yes, you can go for your life. You can report those proceedings of the Crimes Commission which are open to the public but, in doing so, you take the risk of defamation proceedings if the material that you report is not true. You can report things provided that you are confident that what is being said before the royal commission is the truth. Under this amendment, the press would run the risk if it did report what goes on in the Commission, of being the subject of a defamation action if what in fact it was reporting as having been given in evidence in that Commission turns out subsequently not to be true. In other words, it would lose the protection that is available under present defamation law for a fair and accurate report of the Commission's proceedings. Simply because its report is a fair and accurate account of what transpired in the Commission would not under this amendment be enough to give it protection. It would be protected in an action for defamation from someone who was offended by what it wrote only if the evidence given at the Commission could satisfy these criteria of truth or, perhaps in some jurisdictions, truth plus public benefit.

That is the concept, and I acknowledge that it may be perceived by the Press and others as an untoward interference or limitation on the capacity of the Press to report proceedings. But I would argue for it as being really the only practical way, short of requiring all Commission proceedings to be in private, of ensuring that in nearly every case reputation destroying hearsay evidence of the kind which is not admissible in ordinary court proceedings is not given wide currency. I have indicated that the only other alternative is the holding of all these proceedings in private. That does not seem either to me or to the Opposition to be satisfactory, for the reasons I have indicated.

This is in some ways an adventurous amendment breaking new conceptual ground and it might be thought by some to be, as I say, an unwarranted interference on the freedom of the Press. But if the only practical alternative is for the Press not to have power to report at all what is going on in these commissions I think the wisdom of the amendment will be seen as being quite considerable.

The power will be that of the Press to report the proceedings in the way in which it wants to. If it wants to take the risk of reporting these proceedings if it believes the subject matter is in the public interest and, moreover, that it is prepared to run the risk of relying on the truth of the allegations in question, it can report to its heart's content without any limitation. If it is not satisified as to the truth of the material which is being stated in evidence in the Commission's proceedings, it will no doubt be very cautious about running the story, but that, after all, is as it should be. One of the real problems in the whole operation of royal commissions-it will be a problem in the operation of this Crimes Commission-is the readiness of the Press to report what is manifestly scuttlebutt and what is manifestly deleterious to the reputations of others but is ultimately shown to be without foundation.
