This amendment is proposed to an insertion that was made in the House of Representatives during the Committee debate. The Committee of the Whole in the House of Representatives widened the protection which was given under this clause and provided that there could be not merely a refusal to answer questions on the ground of self-incrimination but also a refusal to produce documents.

I think it is clearly understood by the Committee that obtaining access to documents and then analysing the great mass of information which is contained in the documents is one of the significant techniques in trying to combat organised crime which has been developed and demonstrated as a very useful technique by the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. The Government was concerned, on reflection, that the amendment which had been accepted in the House of Representatives was rather broader than was necessary or desirable. The privilege against self- incrimination is, of course, based on the desire to ensure that the individual is not forced to produce information which incriminates himself. It is, of course, firmly rooted in the desire to avoid any temptation which there might be on the part of law enforcement authorities to put undue or improper pressure upon a person and to obtain information from a person which might be damaging.

It is worth referring to a recent High Court of Australia case in which some of the limitations of that privilege against self-incrimination were mentioned by members of the High Court. I think they illustrate clearly that what is desirable is to protect people against incrimination of themselves. We are not concerned to protect non-natural persons or corporations against the right of self-incrimination. Mr Justice Mason, in the case of Rochfort v. Trade Practices Commission, in a judgment which was given on 18 November 1982 and which is not yet reported, pointed out:

In the United States it has been held that the privilege against self- incrimination is available only to natural persons and not to corporations. Indeed, in White it was decided that it is not available to unincorporated associations or at least those which are organized as business enterprises or labour unions. However, in England it has been affirmatively decided that the privilege is availble to corporations

He quotes Triplex Safety Glass Co. v. Lancegaye Safety Glass and other cases as authorities for that proposition. Mr Justice Murphy went rather further than Mr Justice Mason. In the same case, he said:

A person required to produce documents cannot resist production on the ground that this would tend to incriminate another person. The privilege against self- incrimination is a human right, based on the desire to protect personal freedom and human dignity. The history of, and reasons for, the privilege suggest that it should not be extended to artificial persons such as corporations or to large or amorphous voluntary organizations.

He then quotes a string of United States cases and refers to the English decisions which he says are unconvincing and should not be followed here. On this occasion I would agree with the general view which was expressed by Mr Justice Murphy about the human nature of the privilege against self- incrimination.
The United States authorities are of some interest. I refer quickly to White's case, which was mentioned by Mr Justice Mason. In that case it was said:

The constitutional privilege against self-incrimination is essentially a personal one, applying only to natural individuals. It grows out of the high sentiment and regard of our jurisprudence for conducting criminal trials and investigatory proceedings upon a plane of dignity, humanity and impartiality. It is designed to prevent the use of legal process to force from the lips of the accused individual the evidence necessary to convict him or to force him to produce and authenticate any personal documents or effects that might incriminate him. Physical torture and other less violent but equally reprehensible modes of compelling the production of incriminating evidence are thereby avoided.

There is more in the same vein, but I think the flavour of that is an acceptable expression of principle which the Government would endorse. At the same time we think that it is, from a practical point of view, highly desirable that that principle, which we would support, should not be available to protect corporations against the production of documents which may be essential in the combating of organised crime and, indeed, the discovery of organised crime in Australia. We move that amendment, having given the matter further consideration since it was dealt with in the House of Representatives, and would seek the Committee's support for it.

'(a) obstruct or hinder the Commission or a member in the performance of the functions of the Commission; or
(b) disrupt a hearing before the Commission.'.

The amendment relates to the power to punish for contempt of the National Crimes Commission. It is our view that, as presently drafted, clause 22 is much too wide-ranging. It provides that a person shall not (a) insult a member or an acting member in the performance of his functions; (b) interrupt a hearing before the Commission; (c) create a disturbance, or take part in creating or continuing a disturbance, in or near a place where the Commission is holding a hearing; or (d) do any other act that would, if the Commission were a court of record, constitute a contempt of that court. For all or any of those offences the penalty is to be $2,000 or imprisonment for 12 months. While we fully appreciate and accept the necessity for some sanction against actions which might be regarded as analogous to those which, in a judicial context, are described as contempts in the face of the court-disruptive or disturbing behavious such as to make impossible the continuation in a dignified manner of the tribunal's proceedings-we certainly do not regard it as appropriate that there should be penalties of this order for such actions as merely insulting a member of the Commission in the exercise of his powers or functions. It is fair enough to have some sanction against abuse or insult bandied around within the context of the place where the Commission is conducting its hearings, but it is not fair enough at all if intensely critical remarks made outside the ambit of the Commission work place become the subject of contempt of court provisions which are as wide-ranging as these.

It is for that reason that we have proposed to limit rather substantially the scope of this contempt clause so that it would penalise only for behaviour that amounts to (a) obstructing or hindering the Commission or a member in the performance of the functions of the Commission; or (b) disrupting a hearing before the Commission. So it is obstruction or disruption in the more literal senses of those words that we regard as appropriate to deal with in this way, not the more wide-ranging forms of contempt. It may be that we will be told that the clause in question is modelled on that drafted for other tribunals. If so, so much the worse for that drafting, so much the worse for the powers available in relation to those other tribunals. These amendments relate to the terms of office of the commissioners, including the Chairman, his deputies and other members of the National Crimes Commission. The Bill provides at the moment for five-year terms, renewable. The effect of these amendments would be to provide simply for two-year terms, renewable no more than once. The object of the amendment is to ensure some regular turnover at the top of the Crimes Commission and to reduce the chances of the Commission assuming an unaccountable life of its own.

In dealing with matters of this kind one has to draw a balance between two competing considerations. One is the notion of accountability to the Executive and parliament of the body being created; the other, which becomes relevant when we are dealing with sensitive matters involving criminal law and so on, is to endeavour to ensure a degree of independence from the executive government of the day to create a situation where the body exercising functions in a sensitive area is not simply the stooge of the executive government of the day. This is a problem which notoriously arises in the context of secret organisations like the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. It can also be significant in a number of other areas where sensitive policy decisions are being made by statutory authorities or corporations.

In the present context, the Opposition would come down in consideration of that balance on the side of ensuring a greater degree of accountability to the executive government of the day, and through that to the parliament, than independence of the Executive. We see it as being important to acknowledge the principle of independence from the Executive, and that is the subject matter of the next amendment the Opposition will be moving, to clause 25. It will take away the remuneration of the National Crimes Commission from the determination of the Attorney-General and make it the subject of determination by the independent Remuneration Tribunal. Nothing can make an Executive organ quite so much a prisoner of the government of the day than having its bread and butter and the bread and butter of the individuals who constitute it dependent on the patronage of the government of the day.

So we in a sense mark our concern for a degree of independence from the Executive in amendment No. 10, which deals with the remuneration question, and focus here in the context of the terms of an appointment on the question of accountability.

I appreciate that some honourable senators-neanderthal troglodytes, small '1' liberal and otherwise-may not be interested in the nature of this argument but we are doing our best to bring it to their attention nonetheless. The particular objection to this that one has to contemplate is, I suppose, that we would be doing something to destroy the continuity of the organisation if we have turnover as rapid as this. As to this, I say two things. Firstly, there will be no question of destroying the continuity of the staff of the Commission. We are only talking about the top, the commissioners themselves. Secondly, as to those commissioners there is provision for up to four- year terms with the first two-year term being renewable once. Obviously it would not be difficult to organise matters in such a way that there was an overlap of tenure at any given time so as to ensure continuity and not a complete severance in the composition of the body.

SPEECH.PARA: For those reasons we believe this is a practical and workable amendment as well as one that is sensible in principle because it establishes a closer nexus between this body and the Executive government which has given it life. Given the history of crimes commission's in some other jurisdiction, the way in which they have become at worst targets for corruption and at best, in the scale of misbehaviour, have lost their sense of balance and perspective by having people heading them for too long, we feel it is important to guard against this experience. Thus, this amendment is directed to those objectives.

Proposed new clause 36A seeks to put an obligation on members of the National Crimes Commission in relation to their work. The amendment refers to a member or an acting member of the Commission, a person assisting the Commission, a person employed or engaged by the Chairman under section 35 of the National Crimes Commission Bill 1982 or a person appointed to assist the Commission under section 36 of the Bill. We feel this is extremely important. Sub-clause (2) of the proposed new clause states;
A person to whom this section applies who . . .
(a) makes a record of any information; or
(b) divulges or communicates to any person any information,
being information acquired by him by reason of or in the performance of his duties . . . is guilty of an offence.

It has become apparent that for one reason or another, some of them fortuituous, the Opposition's strike rate has been somewhat less than sensational in the Committee stage. Of the 10 amendments we moved, two of relatively lesser importance were accepted by the Government. One of them was passed against the Government's will in a division and seven, for one reason or another, have bitten the dust.

The terms of this motion are simply at attempt to give another opportunity for those more liberally minded honourable senators to reconsider the enormity of the course they have taken in opposing the rational and principled amendments that have been flowing from the Oppostion side of the chamber in the latter part of this afternoon. In particular they should reconsider the implications of the jurisdiction of the Commission remaining as wide as it does under the unamended clause 7, the implications of the search and seizure provision, remaining as it does under clause 14, the implications of the still existing power of the Press to sully reputations which are smeared in a hearsay fashion during such public hearings as are held by the Commission and the provision which remains in the Bill allowing open ended gaol terms for those people who arouse the indignation of the Commission and refuse to co-operate with it. There are important issues of principle in relation not only to those amendments but also to the whole concept of the Bill, which Bill has been the subject of numerous representations to us from professional bodies and others interested in civil liberties and law enforcement around this nation.

It seems to me that we have had a somewhat less than intensive and rational consideration of this legislation during the Committee stage, certainly somewhat less principled and detailed than I might have hoped would be possible. Under those circumstances I believe it is appropriate that the matter go to this Committee for a proper and detailed consideration. The urgency of the matter is now off, given that at least for the moment there does not seem to be a prospect of an early election, which was undoubtedly the major motivation for bringing the legislation on as quickly as was the case. I may, of course, be proven wrong in that respect. It is not a job that need occupy the Senate Committee for more than a few months. Certainly I imagine it would be possible for the Committee to produce a report before the currently scheduled termination of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union in the middle of next year. For all those reasons I commend this legislation to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it regrettable, for reasons which might be slightly different from those put by Senator Evans a while ago when he did not ask for a division, that the Government does not take the course of action that has been recommended by Senator Evans. I say this for separate reasons. I believe that a greater period of contemplation and consideration of this National Crimes Commission Bill would provide for more effective and better legislation. But I will support the Government which, presumably, will oppose Senator Evans's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the unholy alliance which has just been disclosed in this chamber.
—He is on our side.

—I am told that Senator Crichton-Browne is on our side. We have had a fairly full debate in the Committee stage on the National Crimes Commission Bill. Senator Evans said that we have had many representatives. The amazing thing about this Bill is how few representatives there have been. I would have expected more.
—People are worried about dams, too.

—Maybe that is true, Senator. People are very worried about dams. They are certainly not very worried about this Bill. Apart from the Law Council of Australia and two law organisations in Victoria, I have not received a squeak from any organisation. No civil libertarian organisations have come up with any proposals or amendments. I do not know what the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs is expected then to dredge up or what such an investigation by the Committee--
—It could plunder its own intellectual resources.

—Yes. They might dry up in this drought period also, Senator. I would not be terribly concerned about worrying only upon the intellectual resources of the Committee. We have had opportunity tonight to display that. I believe that there has been a good debate on this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: What would be required of us? I am sure that Senator Crichton-Browne and others would consider that the Committee would tip toe about the country to speak to all of the police commissioners, police organisations and the States to find out their views. Not only would the inquiry concern the details of this Bill but also, presumably, whether they liked it. Also, we would have to go to all kinds of organisations to try to search out their views. In my opinion, it is important that there ought to be a crimes commission in this country. It ought to be operating as soon as possible. After all, if these amendments are accepted , the changes will take place on a limited basis and in a limited period. Therefore, the trial period is not great. I believe that it is important that the Crimes Commission--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask Senator Evans to sit down to have his discussion.
—It seems that the unholy alliance wants to get together even closer.
—That is a change. Don't get jealous.
—No, I am not jealous.
—I think it has just fallen apart.

—I think it has fallen apart. But I earnestly say that an investigation by the Committee at this stage would be wasteful. I believe it is important that such a crimes commission be in operation and be seen in existence . The problems of uncontrolled crime in this country are too great to allow this to be an exercise conducted perhaps by a committee over six months. I oppose the motion to refer it to a committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government and all liberal-minded, rational and principled senators who spoke earlier in the debate, I indicate opposition to the suggestion that the National Crimes Commission Bill be sent to a committee. If one looks at the examination of this Bill in the House of Representatives and the Senate, in each case one will find criticism of the way the Bill has been dealt with. Yet I do not believe any piece of legislation, except perhaps the tax legislation, in this current session has received more detailed attention from the Parliament. Unlike the tax legislation, this legislation has been substantially amended, with amendments being brought forward by the Opposition, Government senators and members, and the Australian Democrats. It has received moulding by the Parliament in a way which is more complete than any other item of legislation which we have dealt with certainly in this calendar year.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a healthy respect for the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs and for the work which it carried out on such major legislation as the national compensation legislation which was brought in during 1975, the Family Law Act and so on. I express no disrespect at all for the capacity of that Committee to analyse and to improve legislation. I believe that we are in the unusual situation of not merely having the sort of urgency that Senator Missen stressed of getting something into place which deals with what we would all agree is a national problem-some would say that the presence of organised crime in our community is a national disgrace-but also the objection that on this occasion Parliament itself, in both chambers, has subjected the Bill to critical scrutiny in the Committee stage and has substantially amended the Bill to meet many of the objections that have been raised. I think that, on this occasion, the passage of the Bill should be completed rather than having the experience of what would inevitably be a further considerable delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not support the Opposition's motion to send the National Crimes Commission Bill to a committee. The reasons have been enunciated both by Senator Missen and by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). Basically the need for urgency in this matter is that we believe a great deal of work must be done once this Bill is passed and that any delay will delay the putting into effect of at least the good parts of this Bill-those parts which the Australian Labor Party has commented on and supported.

SPEECH.PARA: The other item is one which commends itself, that is, the point raised by the Minister that a great number of amendments have been accepted in the House of Representatives that have been moved by Government back benchers. Indeed, additional amendments that the Labor Party and ourselves have proposed have been accepted here. If one looks at this Bill in comparison with many other Bills that have been debated fairly furiously in the last few months, it has probably had greater acceptance of suggestions by the Government not only by way of amendment but also prior to the Bill being introduced in this place. On this matter it is as well that that occurred, simply because its operation will be viewed with a great deal of suspicion in the community and also with a great deal of hope. In that case, it is best that it goes forward as soon as possible so those matters that were mooted to be put into legislation may be implemented so that at least some concerted attack at a national level can be made on organised crime. At least we may have, for the first time ever, some effective mechanism for dealing with those enormous operations that have dealt so many blows to our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that it would have been most important to obtain the greatest degree of consensus possible on this matter, because we are establishing a body of a type which is unique in Australia. The National Crimes Commission Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 9 November. It may have been 8 November. The second reading took place on 9 November.
—I think it was 21 October, Senator.
—I am sorry. I am looking at a copy of Hansard.
—That was perhaps the commencement of debate by the Opposition.

—The debate resumed on 9 November on a motion by the Acting Attorney-General (Mr N. A. Brown) that the Bill be now read a second time. It may have been introduced, of course, in late October. Whatever the situation may be, I recall very well the night when it was discussed in the House of Representatives because I was listening to it. Although I have not spoken in the debate thus far, I have had a keen interest in the matter and I examined the amendments that came forward from the Opposition. I was concerned that at least one of those amendments was not adopted. I am concerned also that the States have not been fully consulted on this issue. I make the quite categorical accusation against the Government that the States have not been adequately consulted about this particular issue. The National Crimes Commission Bill was introduced into the House of Representatives, let us say, in late October and the debate on the Bill virtually ranged over one day-from 8.52 p.m. until 1.12 a .m. I do not think that is such a brilliant way of handling a measure such as this.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Lionel Bowen made the comment that the Government should seriously consider redrafting major sections of the Bill. Therefore, he opposed the Bill at the third reading stage. The Bill is now before this chamber. Today-by arrangement, of course-people here have not entered into the Committee stage of the debate. I would have liked to enter into the debate at the Committee stage but I understand that it is late in the session and one is frowned upon if one gets up and wastes taxpayers' money, as it is said, in attempting to address one's mind to major matters that come before this chamber. One is concerned when that sort of accusation is thrown at one because of one's interest in the matter. But I can assure honourable senators that I was quite clear on the issues involved and the amendments that were to be moved. I listened with interest to the debate in the House of Representatives and I listened with interest to the debate in this chamber. Having analysed the amendments, I was prepared to vote the way that I did when I had that opportunity.

A reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs would enable the Committee to have a look at this legislation and it would enable people within the community to have their say. I genuinely believe that people have not had the opportunity to do that. After all, a month's gestation period for a major matter such as this is not a very long time. That is a further reason why I support the proposition put forward by Senator Evans that the matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chaney) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to recap on some of the matters that have just been raised because, as I said, I was not proposing to support the proposal; but I do want to say, as I have alluded to in the past, that I find it regrettable that the Government has not been able seriously to contemplate deferring passage of this legislation until such time as there has been a proper deliberation of this legislation and there have been co-operative negotiations in a sense of good will between the various States, the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory. Before this legislation was introduced there was good will, a spirit of intent to ensure progress, a spirit of intent to ensure that ultimately good, effective legislation would be introduced. It was only with the sudden introduction of this legislation that that good will broke down. I am sure that until that stage there was very much a meeting of the minds of all the participants from the States, the Territory and the Commonwealth. As I said once before, as at 5 November there was to be a report on this matter. All the participants were to work out and ultimately present a final model as to how the National Crimes Commission should operate as agreed upon unanimously by those people. I would have thought that if the Government were serious about this legislation to the point that it wanted to ensure that it would encompass everything and be successful in its application it would have ensured that those negotiations had continued. I do not believe that organised crime is exclusively the prerogative of the conscience or the concern of the Federal Government. In fact, it is very much a matter for the States and the Territory. I am sure that this legislation would be more effective, the endeavours would be more serious and that the attacks upon organised crime would be much more constructive if there had been mutual co- operation and more effective legislation drawn up between the States, the Territory and the Commonwealth, given the fact that the States and the Territory have within their jurisdiction the great majority of criminal legislation. My objection is not to this legislation; it is to the manner, the style and the intent of its introduction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply to indicate that, the Opposition's serious-minded attempts to improve this legislation having substantially failed, as also has its endeavour to refer the matter to a committee for further and better consideration, the Opposition now has no alternative but to oppose the National Crimes Commission Bill at the third reading stage. We did support the Bill at the second reading stage, for reasons which I then outlined, because we thought we had the elements of a potentially successful model to operate in this area of investigating organised crime which was not being effectively coped with by existing law enforcement agencies or the ad hoc system of royal commissions.

SPEECH.PARA: We did, however, indicate at that stage that we were determined to ensure that a crimes commission not be established unless and until there was an effective set of safeguards to ensure that basic liberties were not put at risk by this new institution and that reputations were not wrongfully destroyed. We do not have confidence that that endeavour has been successful. We believe that basic liberties are still at risk under this unamended legislation. We believe that reputations will have a very strong chance of being destroyed unless the powers and jurisdiction of the National Crimes Commission are exercised with very much more caution than has been traditional with royal commissions in the past. We remain profoundly unhappy with the course of events now in relation to the Bill, having sought at all stages to be constructive and co-operative in the evolution of a successful and workable model that would have full cross party and community support. I register my disappointment with that course of events and indicate on behalf of the Australian Labor Party that it now has no alternative but outright opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I do not wish to add to the habit which is growing in this place of having first, second and third reading debates, many of which are largely repetitive but, if I may respond to Senator Evans, I find it strange that he should refer to this legislation as unamended legislation. I think, on a rough count, there were 22 amendments to the legislation carried in the House of Representatives and the Senate and it simply does not warrant that description. The fact of the matter is that a limited number of Opposition amendments were found not to be acceptable to the Senate or to the House of Representatives. I believe that the reasons that have been advanced for not accepting those amendments are reasonable and adequate.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as Senator Crichton-Browne is concerned, I am pleased that he has no objection to the legislation; that rather his objection is to the fact that there was no agreement on the legislation. I would refer back to my explanation at the end of the second reading debate as to what I understand to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —What I was saying was that my primary objection was to the manner rather than the construction of the legislation. If I had my choice, I would have supported the States' model.

—I am grateful to Senator Crichton-Browne for that explanation of his position. I would refer back to the second reading responsethat I gave in which I outlined why he has some slight misconception about the point that was reached with the States. There was not a high degree of consensus about the need for a crimes commission, rather the States pursued a quite different model. As I pointed out in the second reading debate, that did not involve having a single line Crimes Commission which would have the powers which were contained in this Bill. Rather there was a proposal for a beefing up or a strengthening of the criminal intelligence arrangements. The Commonwealth has indicated that it is quite happy to proceed with the strengthening of those arrangements. What we did not think was adequate was the proposal that there should be some ad hoc royal commission arrangements with a body which might co-ordinate them. We did not think that that was an effective approach.The Commonwealth put its basic proposition that it thought that a crimes commission was required in the national interest before the interests of the States. That pattern was not something that was being developed by the States. I commend the third reading of the Bill to the Senate. I thank honourable senators for the support that they have given to the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 16 November, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clauses 1 to 3-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 4, clause 4, proposed new sub-section 4 (5), leave out the sub-section.
This amendment is in similar terms to the provision in the National Crimes Commission Bill 1982 relating to search warrants. The arguments are exactly the same and I do not propose to repeat them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be opposing this amendment for the identical reasons that we opposed it in the National Crimes Commission Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing the amendment for reasons similar to those advanced in the debate on the previous Bill, the National Crimes Commission Bill 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 5 to 7-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's position needs to be stated briefly in relation to clause 6 because this has probably been the most controversial part of the entire Bill, even though it is not the subject of any amendment to be moved by the Opposition. This provision, in effect, removes the privilege, if such ever existed, against self-incrimination in relation to witnesses before royal commissions. Clause 6 seeks to insert a new section 6A in the Royal Commissions Act to provide that it not be a reasonable excuse to refuse to produce documents or fail to answer questions on the ground that to do so might incriminate the person. This has been described in some quarters as horrendous. It has been described by the President of the Law Council of Australia, Mr Gerry Murphy, in a rather belated bit of huffing and puffing in a media release yesterday, as outrageous.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I think it is important to appreciate that the provision is doing no more than restoring a situation which has been assumed to prevail since 1912. The reasons why that is so and how the situation came about are appropriately described in the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Chaney). I do not want to do anything more than simply advert to that and say that we accept the reasoning there set out. It may be that there is some larger constitutional question that remains to be litigated as to whether it is compatible with the Constitution for the right or the privilege against self- incrimination ever to be taken away, even by royal commissions. We simply leave that to one side to be litigated at the appropriate time.

On the merits, the argument is simply, as I think was foreshadowed in the second reading speech, that royal commissions are, after all, aimed at getting at the facts of particular matters, including such things as air crashes and matters of that kind, and exposing them publicly. It would be incompatible with that objective were the privilege against self-incrimination to prevail at the expense of persons answering questions directed to them. That is a very different context from the exploratory or investigative context in which it is proposed that a crimes commission is to operate. That, of course, is another good reason in principle for creating a separate Crimes Commission with limited powers in this respect as distinct from the royal commissions. I do not wish to delay the Committee further, but I think it is important that the fact that there is a reasoned basis for accepting this clause be put on record by the Opposition because it is a matter which has generated a lot of controversy.
Clauses agreed to.
Clause 8.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this clause, as was indicated in the sheet that was circulated, for all the reasons that were explained in relation to the amendments the Opposition sought to pass to clause 20 of the National Crimes Commission Bill. Clause 8 of the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill seeks to insert a new section 6C which, in fact, creates exactly the same procedure of an application to the Federal Court of Australia for an order requiring compliance against someone who refuses to attend or fails to answer questions before a royal commission, a breach of which order will then result in a contempt of court order and, potentially, then an open-ended gaol term for the non-complying witness. The reasons for opposing this provision are exactly the same as those that were articulated in the National Crimes Commission Bill debate. There is no need for me to repeat them.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, however, something of a change in the availability of senators when it comes to the vote on this matter. So this is one which, on this occasion, we propose to put to a division so that the issues of principle can be properly resolved. I simply indicate that the argument is the same to the extent that there is already in existence a sanction available against those who refuse to co-operate with royal commissions by way of non-attendance or non-answering. That sanction is contained in the existing section 6 of the Royal Commissions Act which has been just amended by an earlier clause of this Bill to make provision for a six-month gaol term or a thousand dollar fine for people who do not co-operate in that way. There is a sanction. The Government does not need the additional one that is proposed here after all these years of the operation of the Royal Commissions Act. As I said concerning the National Crimes Commission Bill in similar circumstances, the provision is both draconian and unnecessary. I urge the Committee to oppose clause 8.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the Australian Labor Party amendment for the same reasons that we supported a similar amendment to the National Crimes Commission Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government regrets that this amendment is being put forward and that it is receiving support from the Australian Democrats. As I indicated in the earlier debate, and I do not wish to canvass the points made there in full, this involves a recommendation that was put forward by Mr Costigan which is agreed to by the Government because it appears that the procedure which is set out in the Victorian Evidence Act-there are similar procedures available under the companies legislation-is a more expeditious way of dealing with the difficulty of people who are not prepared to meet the requirements of the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The idea that it is in some way less desirable to refer people who, for one reason or another, do not wish to co-operate with the Commission to a court for consideration and to make them subject to some court order seems to me passing strange in the name of civil liberties. I would have thought that, with the concerns which have been expressed in this debate about the question of royal commissions and crime commissions and so on, a reference to the established courts which are not subject to any of the sorts of doubts which have been expressed would be seen as a quite positive way of ensuring that these considerable powers are exercised in a forum in which the liberties of the subject are, of course, uppermost in the minds of those who are in control.

I do not wish to delay the Committee unnecessarily, but I urge the Democrats, consistent with their stated principle of considering these matters right to the end and considering the arguments raised, to consider again the question of whether reference to a court in the way which is permitted by this clause really is something which is inimical to the liberty of the subject. The Government and I do not see it in those terms. I commend the clause in its present form to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not say that I support the Opposition' s move to delete a double penalty for the same reason that I supported the deletion of the double penalty in the National Crimes Commission Bill. Nothing that the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) has said convinces me to change the view that I had formed after studying this Bill and the clause. I have stated on a number of occasions that I am in a situation where I must listen attentively to the debate, particularly in the Committee stages, but I still wish to maintain the position that I had on the previous Bill. I reinforce that by voting against the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful that Senator Harradine has indicated to the Committee the basis of his opposition because that was mentioned but not dealt with in the Committee debate on the National Crimes Commission Bill. I think if Senator Harradine was listening he would recall that when I raised the matter, Senator Evans shook his head and indicated that that was not the ground on which the opposition was putting forward the amendment. Like Senator Harradine, I was certainly concerned at the suggestion of double penalty when it was raised as an objection to this clause, not in the Senate but elsewhere. I think it is important to look at the actual situation and to see that, in fact, this does not involve a double penalty.

SPEECH.PARA: In both this Bill and the Bill that we have already considered, an offence is committed if somebody does not comply with the legal requirements to give evidence which is not subject to some valid legal objection. In other words, it is quite true that a failure to give evidence can give rise to a situation where one could be taken to court and prosecuted for an offence. I think Senator Evans in his comments on the clause referred to the actual provisions in the Act which permit a prosecution. I do not in any sense deny that the Government's position is not based on that not being the case. We agree that it is, as indeed it is under the National Commission legislation.

The important point to add to a matter which was raised by Senator Harradine is that in a situation where there is a refusal to answer or provide information the matter is then sent of to the court which, after giving due consideration to the certificate which is put before it, has to make the decision on whether it should order the information to be given. It is in a circumstance in which an order is made by the court that the information should be given and that order is subsequently disobeyed that the possible liability for punishment for contempt arises. In other words, it is a separate subsequent refusal to comply which gives rise to a separate possibility of punishment. In exactly the same way, of course, the Commission could call the witness back before it. The witness could again refuse to give evidence and could again be subjected to punishment by the courts for a breach of the law. Where there are repetitive acts of refusal to meet legal obligations there can be a repetitive liability for punishment.

The same situation applies if somebody strikes another over the left ear. That person is liable for punishment for assault. If that person came round the next day and struck the other on the same ear it would not be double jeopardy to impose a separate punishment for that separate offence. There is no question here of there being liability for a dual penalty for the same unlawful act. There would have to be separate and successive unlawful acts before there would be liability to more than one penalty. If the objection on the part of some honourable senators to the clause as it stands is based on a concern that a single act should not give rise to a double penalty-of course, the basic objection to double jeopardy in the law is that one should not be punished twice for the same offence-I make it absolutely clear to the Committee that that is not the case here. We are looking at the possibility of successive breaches of the law.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rooted in the original defence.

—The important potential safeguard for the person who is appearing before a royal commission is that he gets a chance-before a quite different forum, before a court-to have the question of whether he is required to answer tested. In other words, it is not just a blind following on from the certificate of the royal commission. I refer the Committee to proposed new section 6C (2) which appears on page 6 of the Bill. The proposed new section provides:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a certificate is given under sub-section (1),--
That is, the certificate from the royal commission--
the court, upon application by the Attorney-General,-
So another step is required; the Attorney-General must bring an application before the court-

may inquire into the case and, if it is satisfied that the person to whom the certificate relates has, as mentioned in the certificate, refused or failed to comply with the requirement in contravention of section 3 or 6, or refused or failed to answer a question in contravention of section 6, may order the person to comply with the requirement . . .

In other words, under this application the court is not visiting a punishment upon the person; it is making an order that the person should comply with the requirement. It is only if there is a subsequent failure to meet that requirement of the court that any question of a punishment for contempt can arise. I think I said earlier-perhaps during the Committee stage of the National Crimes Commission Bill-that this is a situation where one is putting before a court rather than a royal commission this fundamental question as to whether an objecting witness should be required to answer. I would see that as being much more consistent with the protection of civil liberties than would otherwise be the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had hoped to not have had to intervene again in the consideration of this matter but it is necessary because the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), while being perfectly technically accurate in everything he said, has quite misrepresented the practical effect of what these clauses are all about. If I refuse to answer a question as to the source of some information which I have or if I refuse to answer a question, say, as to my whereabouts on a particular night and for refusing to answer one or other of those questions I am convicted under clause 6 of the Royal Commissions Amendment Bill and spend six months in gaol, it is not much consolation for me when I get out of gaol to find that I am the subject of a proceeding under the Federal Court of Australia. Should I again refuse to comply with that request and find myself in gaol again for an indefinite period this time for contempt of the Federal Court, it is not much consolation for me to learn, when I am cooling my heels in gaol for the second time for refusing to answer exactly the same question, that, technically, different questions were put on different occasions or that a technically different sequence of legal events got me into gaol.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality of the matter is that, as Senator Harradine said by way of interjection, in each case the thing is rooted in the same course of events or in the same question that one has refused to answer. One can be punished not just once, not just twice, but on multiple occasions under the clauses as they now stand for refusing to answer one particular question-the same question repeated on subsequent occasions. In that sense-not in the technical sense-there is a degree of double jeopardy. The Government already has a punishment provision; it does not need the open-ended punishment provision that is now contained in this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make one further comment. I am sorry that Senator Evans saw my explanation as being only technically correct. I point out that with respect to the provisions as they would stand if his amendment succeeded it would also be open to a royal commission to bring a witness back on successive occasions and to ask the same question. In those circumstances there would be an ongoing liability to successive punishments in the event that the witness was improperly-that it, improperly under the various sections of the Royal Commissions Act-refusing to answer the questions. The only difference in substance, I would suggest, is that there is not a limit on the court with respect to the duration of punishment which may be imposed. But in terms of the possibility that a person who continuously refuses to comply with the requirements of the royal commission to answer a question which is properly asked and for which there is no legal justification for refusal there is exactly the same liability for successive acts of punishment. My concern and the Government's concern is that the operation of these sections under the Evidence Act and the Companies Act has indicated a more practical working mechanism for the procedures. My personal preference-I express it because it is not a matter on which I have some Government direction-is that bringing an allegedly defaulting person before the courts and requiring the courts to be satisified that the various tests contained in the sections as to when a person has to answer and when a person does not have to answer are met is more likely to protect the liberty of the subject than would otherwise be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Oppostion, I indicate that although the Opposition has considerable sympathy with the objectives sought to be assured by Senator Chipp's amendment, and has in fact wrestled with the matter for some time, on balance it is persuaded by the kind of arguments that were hinted at by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in his reply . SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Evans and Senator Chaney for undertaking to look further into the matter , also Senator Missen for his support. Just for the record, let me say in response to Senator Chaney that section 6M of the Royal Commission Act 1902 does say that it is an indictable offence to inflict violence, damage, loss or disadvantage to any witness before any royal commission. —There is also a criminal injuries compensation scheme under which people get actual cash where a criminal injury has been inflicted upon them.

The speech read as follows-
This Bill will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of comprehensive double taxation agreements with the Republic of Korea and the Kingdom of Norway.
The agreements, which were signed on 12 July 1982 and 6 May 1982 respectively, deal with all forms of income flowing between Australia and each of the other two countries.
Neither can enter into force until all necessary constitutional processes are completed both by Australia and the other country.
Double taxation agreements have two primary objects-the elimination of international double taxation and the prevention of fiscal evasion.
The first of these objects is achieved by the contracting countries agreeing to the allocation of taxing rights between them.
There are various ways by which this is done, depending upon the nature of the income involved.
For example, some types of income will be taxed only in the country of residence while other income may be taxed only in the country in which it has its source.

A third category is comprised of income which may be taxed in both countries, with the country of source generally agreeing to limit its tax, and the country of residence of the taxpayer agreeing to allow a credit against its tax on such income for the tax paid in the other country.
Both of the new treaties accord in all essential respects with the position that Australian governments have taken over the years in relation to double taxation agreements.
Each provides for the country of source to limit its tax on dividends, interest and royalties.
Under the Korean agreement, the country of source is to limit its tax to 15 per cent of the gross amount of any dividend, interest or royalty income flowing to the other country.

For its part, Australia will reduce the rate of withholding tax on dividends flowing to Korea from the normal 30 per cent rate to the 15 per cent rate specificed in the agreement but, as the rate of withholding tax on interest under Australia's domestic law is 10 per cent, this will not be affected by these arrangements.

In Australia royalties paid to non-residents are taxed on the ordinary assessment basis and, accordingly, the limit specified by the agreement will not affect the amount of Australian tax on royalties unless the tax which would otherwise be assessed is greater than 15 per cent of the gross amount of the royalties paid to Korean residents.
For its part, Korea will reduce its rate of tax on dividends, interest and royalties from the existing 25 per cent to the 15 per cent rate specified in the agreement.

In some cases, however, Korea may, in accordance with its industry incentive legislation, wholly or partially exempt from Korean tax certain interest and royalty payments made to Australian residents.

If nothing were done to avoid the situation, the tax so foregone by Korea would simply result in a corresponding reduction in the credit to be allowed by Australia against its tax on the relevant interest and royalty payments. In other words, the Australian revenue would pick up the tax foregone by Korea, thus nullifying the incentive.

To avoid that result, provision is made in the agreement for Australia, as a ' tax sparing' measure, to allow a credit against its tax for tax foregone by Korea under agreed Korean incentive legislation as if notional tax equal to 10 per cent of the interest or royalty income had been paid to the Republic of Korea.
These tax sparing arrangements are broadly similar to those which have been included in agreements with other developing countries in the region.
Under the Norwegian agreement the tax of the country of source is to be limited to 15 per cent in the case of dividends and to 10 per cent for both interest and royalties.

Again, this limit will not affect Australia's rate of withholding tax on interest nor, since Norway does not at present tax interest or royalties paid to non-residents, will it affect the position regarding interest or royalties flowing from Norway to Australia.
However, if Norway were to impose a tax on interest or royalties in the future, the limit of 10 per cent would apply.

As with the Korean agreement, the limit on the tax on royalties will only affect Australian tax on royalties paid to Norway where tax on the ordinary assessment basis would otherwise have exceeded the limit expressed in the agreement.

Both agreements contain measures for the formal relief of double taxation of income that may be taxed in both countries, with the country of residence of the taxpayer affording the necessary relief by the allowance of a credit against its tax for tax paid to the country of source.

So far as Australian residents are concerned, income in respect of which a limit is imposed by the agreements on the tax of the country of source-dividends , interest and royalties-will generally be taxed here with credit being allowed for the tax of the country of source.
However, foreign source dividends received by Australian companies will continue to be effectively tax-free in Australia under existing legislation.
Other income that is taxed in full in the country of source will continue to be exempt from Australian tax.

So far as the object of preventing fiscal evasion is concerned, provisions are made in each agreement for the exchange of information and for consultation between the tax administrations of the contracting countries.
A memorandum containing more detailed explanations of technical aspects of the Bill and of the agreements will be made available to honourable senators. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The purpose of the Bill is to give effect to the Area to be Avoided in Bass Strait, in the vicinity of the offshore petroleum production facilities, to which entry is prohibited to unauthorised Australian vessels over 200 tons gross tonnage. The Area to be Avoided replaces the existing restricted area first established in 1976 and enlarged in 1980. The existing restricted area is advisory only. However, with the increasing number of platforms in the area, and their economic importance to Australia, the Government considers it appropriate that additional steps should be taken to increase the effectiveness of the restrictions, enhancing the protection of the offshore platforms and the safe movement of shipping in the region.

Under the present provisions of the Act, and in accordance with the 1958 Convention on the Continental Shelf, safety zones of 500 metres have been declared around each platform, prohibiting entry by any unauthorised vessel. The Area to be Avoided established under this Bill will extend approximately 50 nautical miles from the coast to envelop the offshore platforms and submarine pipelines. Its outer boundary will lie about 5 nautical miles beyond the platforms while its inner boundary will follow the outer limit of the 3 mile territorial sea. Complementary legislation will be introduced by Victoria extending the Area to be Avoided from the outer limit of the territorial sea to the coast of Victoria.
The Areas to be Avoided established by the Commonwealth and the State legislation will have the same boundaries as the present advisory restricted area.

The restrictions established under the Bill will be binding on Australian vessels over 200 tons gross tonnage. For foreign vessels, the restrictions have been promulgated as an Area to be Avoided in accordance with arrangements approved by the International Maritime Organisation. The restrictions will become mandatory for foreign vessels as their governments pass appropriate legislation. The International Maritime Organisation has also approved a traffic separation scheme to the south of the Area to be Avoided to assist ship navigation.
Arrangements are in place involving sea, air and radar surveillance of Bass Strait to ensure that restrictions are complied with by shipping.

Turning to the details of the Bill, clause 3 inserts a new Division 6A into the 1967 Act and clause 4 adds a new schedule 6 to the Act defining the boundaries of the Area to be Avoided. The new section 140C provides for a penalty of a fine of up to $50,000 or imprisonment up to 5 years for unauthorised entry into the Area to be Avoided or both. The penalty may be imposed on the owner, the master and any officer in charge of the vessel.

In order to ensure that the new provisions can be carried out effectively, authorised persons are given powers of enforcement set out in the new section 140D. These include the power to board a vessel, to order the removal of a vessel from the Area to be Avoided and to order a disabled vessel to accept assistance. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: EXPORT MARKET DEVELOPMENT GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 September, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the unavoidably absent Senator Walsh, who would normally handle the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill, I indicate that the Opposition does not oppose it. It is a belated implementation of part of the package announced in relation to industry on 19 July which involved a variety of measures. It is perhaps indicative of the enthusiasm with which the Government approaches the task of providing export incentives that it has taken until December to get this fairly small and innocuous but helpful piece of legislation off the ground and into effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation arises against the backdrop of a most unhappy balance of trade situation-a $9,000m deficit in the last financial year and with the country looking down the barrel of an even larger deficit this year. Against that background it becomes very important, particularly for the manufacturing industry of this country, to have incentive mechanisms of the kind contained in this legislation set in place and updated so far as their financial contents are concerned. The primary effect of the Bill, apart from some other aspects contained in it, is to update the value of the support which was contained in the original 1974 legislation introduced by the Labor Government. Thus it is, for example, that the maximum annual grant is increased by virtue of this legislation from $100,000 to $200,000.

However, I make the point that any pride the Government may have in these increases should be tempered both by the years of parsimony which have eroded the real value of export incentives and also by the other measures which the Government is taking on this occasion; in particular, the simultaneous abandonment of the Export Expansion Grants Scheme. Using the figures supplies by Mr Hurford, the Opposition spokesman in the other place, in 1979-80 the total allocation under that grants scheme to all industries was $162.7m. Of that total , manufacturing industry received $153.7m. However, the estimates for the current financial year, with the abandonment of that grants scheme and the continuation of only the Export Market Development Grants Scheme show that the total equivalent assistance will be only $36m. So what we are in fact confronted with when we look at export support as a whole and not just in the context of this particular program is a cost cutting exercise. There may have been some policy justification for that approach being taken to the grants scheme but we would not wish anyone to be under any illusion about the ineffectiveness and insufficiency of the Government's support in this crucial area.

When these points were made by Mr Hurford in a speech the contents of which ranged over the series of relevant policy issues, which there is no need for me to repeat here, the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) did not deign to give him anything in the nature of a reply. I believe that that amounted to a silent acknowledgement of the accuracy of Mr Hurford's comments and of the Government's slowly disintegrating-perhaps increasingly rapidly disintegrating- interest in real incentives to export. I think the Government has made it plain by these and other measures that its real interests are with, if anyone, the miners and the farmers of this country and not with that sector that can most immediately stimulate employment and provide a sound base for future maintenance and increases in the standard of living of Australians; namely, the manufacturing and service industries, although I notice that tourism is given some support by this measure. Following those brief remarks, I repeat that the Opposition supports this Bill and wishes it an appropriately speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my intention to justify the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill and answer some of the concerns expressed by Senator Evans. As he mentioned, the Bill must be considered in the light of the Industries Assistance Commission report on export incentives, put down in February of this year, and the Government's total package of industry assistance which includes its response to the IAC report, announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) last July. This Bill implements that part of the total package which relates to export incentives.

SPEECH.PARA: But for the constraints of time I would have placed this Bill in the historical context of export incentives in Australia. Suffice it to say that they were first introduced in 1961 in the form of two schemes, one rewarding export improvement and the other subsidising market development. Dual schemes of the same nature exist today although that rewarding export improvement has once been abandoned, then reinstated and, further to the Prime Minister's announcement and now by this Bill, it is to be abandoned again. That relating to subsidising promotional activities is to be expanded and further refined. The question therefore is whether governments have been twice right or twice wrong in relation to the practice of recent years in export development. Fundamental questions arise relating to the need for export orientated industry and, if such need exists, the benefit and cost of direct export incentives.

As stated by Senator Evans on behalf of the Opposition, Australia's trading account position is far from satisfactory. In 1980-81 Australia had a trade deficit of $372m. By 1981-82 it had increased almost tenfold, to $3,321m, giving a current account deficit of over $9,000m. The export of goods increased by only 2 per cent that year whereas the value of imports increased by 17 per cent. The vulnerability of having to rely upon massive capital inflow to balance the books has already been recognised by government. On 14 December 1981 the Minister for Trade and Resources, Mr Anthony, said:

We cannot assume that this level of capital inflow will continue to compensate for any trading shortcomings. No country can rely on capital inflow to this degree. Already this year, capital inflow has slowed. At the same time the current account deficit has continued to grow.

Our trading position is of great concern. What, in that light, has happened to exports over the last decade? In general terms there has been an average annual growth of 2.1 per cent. The classifications have, however, changed. Primary sector exports other than mining have declined from 51 per cent to 45 per cent. Manufactured exports have declined from 24 per cent to 20 per cent and mining sector exports have increased from 22 per cent to about 31 per cent. Markets have also changed. The European Economic Community used to take 18 per cent of our exports but that has been reduced to about 11 per cent. The level of exports to the United States of America fell from 11 per cent to 7.8 per cent. Japan has stayed steady, with a fall from 26 per cent to 24 per cent, while the Association of South East Asian Nations and other Asian markets have substantially increased from 12.3 per cent to 19.3 per cent. The other growth area-the Middle East-has seen an increase from 1.9 per cent to 3.8 per cent.

Although the IAC has reservations about drawing conclusions from a comparison of the gross domestic product and export levels of various countries, it nevertheless stated in its report on export incentives that in 1978 Australian exports represented about 12 per cent of gross national product which proportion was lower than that in most other developed countries. Furthermore, in 1963 exports represented 15 per cent of GNP. Finally, whilst the ratio of exports to GNP declined for Australia during that period, the ratio increased for most other developed countries for which data is available.

Therefore, our export performance has been one of small, steady but nevertheless comparatively disappointing growth, with significant change in markets and significant change in the composition of export products. It shows an increasing dependence on the fluctuating fortunes of the mining sector, the consequences of which we are now suffering, and still a subtantial though slightly lower dependence on the rural sector, for which we shall suffer as a result of this drought. Notwithstanding the drought, the Bureau of Industry Economics does not foresee any substantial increased access to world agricultural commodity markets for Australia and, if the United States this year is any guide, a good crop year in Australia may not have resulted in significant reward because of the inability of importing countries to pay for the product. Our performance has not, therefore, been as good as we might imagine. It has adapted to change only slowly, and it is narrowly based and, therefore, vulnerable. The contribution of export incentives must be considered in the light of that record.

Who, therefore, has benefited from the schemes? The IAC estimated that in 1979- 80 manufacturing industries received 81 per cent and 95 per cent of the total grants under each of the Export Market Development Grants Scheme and the Export Expansion Grants Scheme respectively. Rural and mining industries, accounting for the substantial proportion of Australian exports, each received only 3 per cent of total export grants. Thus it would appear that the incentives have been directed to, or at least particularly taken advantage of by, the manufacturing sector. Is that a criticism? On a resource allocation argument, that might be said to be inefficient. However, if an export orientated manufacturing industry is important, this particular system might be justified. Furthermore, Australia' s apparent vulnerability, which has now been shown with drought conditions and low mineral prices, appears to support the principle of export diversification.

Certainly, the importance of an export orientated manufacturing industry has the support of such bodies as the Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry-the Jackson Committee-and the Crawford Study Group and remains government policy. Sir Phillip Lynch, as Minister for Industry and Commerce, when reporting on the Crawford report, said:

The Government will continue to pursue policies to encourage the development of competative manufacturing industries that are more export orientated, involve specialisation in particular skills and products, use advanced technology, draw on wider markets to take advantage of scale economies, have innovative management, pursue increased productivity and rely less on government support.
But in looking at the role of export incentives in relation to such objectives, one is struck by the apparent inconsistency in relying less on government support. The IAC also considers that:
A healthy export sector is one which can be internationally competative with minimum levels of government support.

But if export incentives do encourage specialisation, updating of technology and improved management skills or encourage market expansion and development beyond the financial capacity of the manufacturer, there may well be a countervailing argument. In the debate on the motor vehicle industry last November I argued for the concept of export facilitation as an incentive for those able to produce an internationally competitive product. Again, economies of scale benefit from specialisation and attendant advanced technology, and I think that the adoption of that principle by government has shown reward. The export of engines by General Motors-Holden's Pty Ltd is an example of the utilisation of Australia's natural resource advantages and a realistic incentive to guide industry in a desirable national direction.

Somewhat similarly, in May of this year when speaking to the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill 1982, I argued for accelerated depreciation on plant and depreciation on buildings on the basis that our manufacturing industry cannot be expected reasonably to compete with overseas industry which is receiving such benefits. I am pleased to see that this fact has been recognised by the Government and included in the total package of benefits of Australian industry. Thus I would support in certain circumstances what might be called a distortion by the purists, dependent upon an analysis of the ultimate objective. Therefore, it is relevant to see how the IAC assessed the contribution of the schemes.

Although accepting the difficulty in obtaining quantifying evidence, the IAC could find little expansion in exports attributable to the EEG Scheme. Furthermore, it found little evidence from witnesses that they had used grant money to invest in higher technology plant and equipment or to undertake research concerned with the development of export orientated products. In other words, it found little evidence that the scheme had produced direct long term advantage. It found that the EMDG payments had been more successful, mainly because they have increased awareness of export opportunities and enabled some exporters to establish a foothold in export markets and achieve export sales which would be sustainable in the absence of assistance. Overall, however, it recommended that both schemes be terminated. Its rationale was largely that the export sector cannot be considered in isolation from other sectors of the economy, as to a large extent a healthy export sector is contingent on the development of an efficient and competitive industry structure as part of the economy as a whole. That structure will be better achieved by the implementation of a policy of general reduction in protection which would encourage the development of export and other relatively low cost activities, by reducing the cost penalties resulting from the provision of relatively high levels of assistance to many import competing industries.
To quote the Prime Minister, the Government's decision accepts the concept of:

. . . a winding down of direct assistance to exports. At the same time the package is designed to encourage industrial investments and increase efficiency, by particularly providing accelerated depreciation on plant, depreciation on income producing buildings and maintaining the industrial research and development incentives scheme.

The Government has reaffirmed its desire to foster a healthy export industry sector and to facilitate the structural adjustment of industry towards greater export orientation but has rejected that this can be best achieved by providing financial incentives to increase exports. On the other hand, the Government did not reject the principle of direct assistance to encourage exports. It might be said that there is an inconsistency or, alternatively, that all eggs are being placed in the one more efficient basket. There is probably some truth in both propositions. But the EMDG Scheme can be justified by its ultimate objective in much the same way as export facilitation. It enables an industry to develop export markets which it may not otherwise be financially able to develop.

There is one other complication I wish to mention. That is the substantial growth of protectionism in world trade in recent years. Australia has argued in recent times that the multilateral winding back of subsidies to international trade is desirable. Furthermore, in September of last year Australia signed the Code on Subsidies and Countervailing Duties. Arguably, the EEG Scheme is in fact prohibited by the code. Thus by its action the Government is not only endorsing the code but, by not redirecting the whole of the incentive into a legitimate scheme, it is taking a small step to endorse by practice the principles of its recent trade initiative. It will be remembered that at the time of the call by the Prime Minister for such an initiative there was the criticism that Australia was not prepared to show a lead.

I do, however, sound a warning. The most impressive economic performance over the last decade has been that of Singapore, which has gained its achievements through increased trade sponsored by such government assistance-I shall not list all the examples-as follows: Exports are not subject to value added tax, turnover tax, development tax, or capital gains tax; there was a 50 per cent reduction in company tax for export income profits; approved companies are given a concessional tax rate on profits-a 90 per cent reduction-for five years; and there are double deductions for export promotional expenses. The majority of the IAC said:
The Commission considers that the principle of matching export incentives with those provided by other countries is not a sound principle on which to base longer term economic policies.

That may be so as economic theory, but Australia cannot expect its industries to compete against an unfair advantage artificially created by a competing government. That was the point that I made in an earlier speech on the subject of depreciation allowances.

If, therefore, other governments are not prepared to comply with not only the letter but also the spirit of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, Australia must not be prepared to sacrifice its export potential in the manufacturing sector for an ideal. We must, therefore, develop a system with sufficient flexibility to determine when it is in the nation's long term best interests to help industry in the short term to meet unfair competition.
