The Social Security Amendment Bill 1982 proposes to amend the Social Security Act 1947 in two areas. It has been introduced in response to anomalies in the operation of the Act that have come to the Government's attention recently. The budgetary implications of the proposed amendments are relatively minor. The Bill proposes to pay family allowance to the parents of unemployed school leavers during the six week period they are not qualified for unemployment benefit. It will also extend eligibility for sickness benefits to a number of people to whom it should be paid but two are presently excluded because of the wording of the legislation. It will also enable, for the first time, all sickness beneficiaries who are otherwise eligible to receive supplementary (rental) allowance.
Assistance for parents of unemployed school leavers

Under current provisions when a student child over the age of 16 years ceases to be a full-time student, family allowance ceases to be payable from the following family allowance period. Where a school-leaver does not immediately or quickly obtain employment, there is a six week waiting period before unemployment benefit becomes payable to the former student. Thus there has been a relatively short period during which no specific support has been available to families for the maintenance of an unemployed school-leaver. This has created difficulties for some families where the parents are on low incomes.

The Government now proposes to treat such a child as a student over the six week period or the relevant part of that period. In this way payment of family allowance, including handicapped child's allowance and double orphan's pension, can continue during the period the child remains unemployed and otherwise qualified. Similarly, the amendment provides that where the school-leaver is the child of a pensioner or beneficiary, additional pension or benefit for the child shall continue to be paid for the relevant part of the deferral period.

The amendment will operate from the family allowance pay period which commenced on 15 October 1982 and in relation to pension and benefit instalments falling due on or after 1 November 1982. The cost of this initiative is estimated as some $5m in a full year at the current rates.

I also take this occasion to mention another initiative affecting student children but one for which legislative amendment is not required. As from the beginning of 1983 the amount of income which a student may have while attracting family allowance or additional pension or benefit is to be increased. The Government has decided to increase the amount of income which a student may have while continuing to be regarded as a 'dependant' from $1,800 to $2,500 for those living at home. For students living away from home, the limit has been raised from $2,600 to $3,600.
Sickness Benefits

Under the current provisions of the Social Security Act, a person may qualify for a sickness benefit if he is temporarily incapacitated for work because of sickness or accident and has thereby suffered a loss of salary, wages or other income. the loss of income must arise from an incapacity for work. Legal advice provided to the Department of Social Security has indicated that this loss of income requirement is only met where a claimant was actually receiving income immediately before the incapacity occurred or where he would have definitely received an income if the incapacity had not occurred. accordingly, it has become necessary to assist people adversely affected by this requirement by providing special benefit. To overcome this anomaly, the Bill extends eligibility for sickness benefit to two categories of people who may currently be disadvantaged.

First, eligibility will be extended to people who are able to show that, but for their incapacity, they would have been qualified to receive unemployment benefit. The rate of sickness benefit paid to these people will be limited to the appropriate amount of unemployment benefit. This limitation ensures precisely comparable treatment with unemployment beneficiaries who become incapacitated for work and are transferred to sickness benefit. Elegibility will also be specifically extended to former invalid pensioners and recipients of sheltered employment allowance, and to former recipients of rehabilitation allowance, who had previously been paid sickness benefit, invalid pension or sheltered employment allowance. Such persons may not be eligible under the more general new provision since they may not be eligible for unemployment benefit. The rate of sickness benefit paid in such cases will reflect the previous pension or allowance payment.

The initiatives governing payment of supplementary (rent) allowance to sickness beneficiaries are significant. At present a person who is transferred from unemployment benefit to sickness benefit is not qualified to receive supplementary allowance. Similarly, an incapacitated person who has not suffered an actual loss of income but who is granted sickness benefit under the new provision would not be eligible for supplementary allowance. The Bill extends eligibility, under the normal conditions, to both of those groups. Thus for the first time all sickness beneficiaries otherwise eligible will be able to claim supplementary allowance. Consistent with the relevant provision governing the payment of supplementary allowance to sickness beneficiaries, eligibility for the allowance will commence after a six week period.

A further minor but important advance in this area contained in the Bill is a provision which enables all pensioners who were previously receiving supplementary assistance or incentive allowance to receive supplementary allowance immediately on transfer to sickness benefit, rather than wait for the six weeks qualifying period. The cost of the amendments to the sickness benefit and supplementary allowance provisions is estimated at $2.5 million in a full year at current rates. The amendments to the sickness benefit and supplementary allowance provisions will take effect as soon as the Bill receives the Royal Assent. This Bill corrects important anomalies in the Social Security Act which have been drawn to our attention as a cause of hardship to certain groups in the community. It is a Bill that I believe deserves the support of all honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: 'The Ironworkers': McKeon Family-Department of Foreign Affairs; Alleged Offences by Officers

PROCTEXT.PARA: 'The Ironworkers': McKeon Family-Department of Foreign Affairs; Alleged Offences by Officers

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the adjournment to make some observations about a well-produced book called The Ironworkers which was written by Robert Murray and Kate White. It deals with a very important segment of the trade union movement. We all know about Robert Murray from some of his earlier publications, including The Split which dealt with a turbulent era of the Australian Labor Party in the 1950s and another excellent book which dealt with Australia between the two wars. Likewise, this book deals in full with the leadership of the Federated Ironworkers Association. It not only deals with the current leaders but also goes back to the formation of the union which was before World War I.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise primarily because an error appears on pages 286 and 287 of this excellent publication. As a former official of the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Labor Party, I want to correct this mistake. The book discusses the torrid period during the struggle for control of the union. It states that in 1965 the National Secretary of the Ironworkers Union, Laurie Short, in an act of compassion suggested that a man named Ken McKeon should be given Australian Labor Party membership. I used the word 'compassion'. In that context, I want to develop the saga of the McKeon family to indicate why Ken McKeon was not given membership. I will be as quick as I can.

I take the Senate back to my first dealings with the McKeon family who lived in Concord. My story has a small beginning. It began on a Sunday morning. I had a fox terrier dog named Jeff. I know that people such as Senator Douglas McClelland who is a dog lover will appreciate this aspect. I went along to my place of worship. The three McKeon boys were in the churchyard. They were always vicious. They took umbrage because my dog followed me into the church. Whatever denomination people are, I do not believe it was the end of the world because that inoffensive dog wanted to follow me into the church.

Ken McKeon, who was the greatest degenerate of any member of the trade union movement in New South Wales, laid my dog out with a brick. I picked up a piece of three by two in order to even things up because there were three McKeons and only myself. It was unfortunate that, with the dog lying in a pool of blood, the father of the McKeon boys, who was a policeman, threatened to arrest me. Of course, there was only one victor and it was not me. I carried the dog the half mile to my home. I said to my mother: 'One day I will even that up'.

I will take the saga of the McKeon family a bit further. During the early 1950s , Ken McKeon was one of Ernie Thornton's henchmen in the Federated Ironworkers' Association. I state quite fairly that I do not have phobias if someone is a Marxist. A man whom I often see today-we are on good terms although our politics are miles apart-is Jack McPhillips who was a prominent official of the ironworkers union during that era. The difference is that Jack McPhillips has remained loyal to his Marxist principles. But the McKeons used Catholicism, Marxism and toadying to the boss for their own ends.

I started by saying that Ken McKeon was the greatest degenerate who was ever in the trade union movement in Australia. I will illustrate this point. A friend of mine, Wally Carlton, a prominent Sydney businessman, was an FIA member at the Westinghouse Brake Company. The modus operandi that Ken McKeon would use consisted of knocking on the doors of delegates that he did not like when he knew they were out, abuse their wives and then sometimes expose himself. That was the sort of man he was. It did not end there. When he was an official of the ironworkers union, he used his conscripted typists as his bedmates. It was of all the more concern when it was well known that he used to attend the VD clinic in Sydney.

I will put this matter in clear terms. I know that the facts are sordid but this must be said. I will give honourable senators the whole story of Ken McKeon . When he left the Communist Party, of course, he looked for somewhere else where he could feather his nest. He ultimately finished up as part of the boss class, as an industrial officer for the Chicago Bridge Company. He then went to Bernard Smith and subsequently to another firm. That is the saga of Ken McKeon. I know that Senator Douglas McClelland will agree with my comments. In 1965 Laurie Short had a moment of weakness and suggested that Ken McKeon should be forgiven. I believe in dealing with this matter on a sectarian line. When Louis Budenz, who was the leader of the Communist Party in the United States, wanted a good job, he embraced Catholicism and got a job at the Jesuit University at Fordham. McKeon operated in the same way. The McKeon family, when they were not using Catholicism, were using Marxism. Therefore, in 1965, when Short suggested that he was a reformed character, I said: 'He will only get in over my dead body '. He never got in! I was supported by the General Secretary of the Labor Party, Bill Colbourne, by the then member for Kingsford-Smith, Dan Curtin, and the present Chairman of Committees in the Legislative Council of New South Wales, Clive Healy. I make that point deliberately because when people read this book I do not want them to believe what is written in error, namely, that a super degenerate, which is what McKeon was, ever came into the Labor Party.
I want to deal with his two brothers because they were also the assailants on my dog and me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the dog get better?

—He did and he lived for another seven years in spite of that vicious attack. With regard to the other two McKeons, one joined the Democratic Labor Party and the other had membership for a long while in the Australian Labor Party. Let met give the Senate my reasons for indicting them. They were more cunning. They were church wardens in the various parishes in the Catholic Archdiocese in Sydney. The remarkable thing about them was that one Sunday they would go around with the plate. But the next Sunday, if somebody else went around, it would be noticed that there was more money on the plate. Honourable senators can draw the conclusion that the McKeon family was the dregs of society . I make that point because I believe in settling scores. So the situation is that Ken McKeon was denied membership of the Labor Party personally by me due to that vicious attack on my dog. But, apart from that, there was no way, when we heard the other aspects about his sexual peculiarities and other things, that he would be accepted into the Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend this book The Ironworkers. It is an excellent book. It is 99.9 per cent accurate. But the .01 per cent remaining portrayed the low grade people that the McKeons were. I conclude by saying that I have kept faith. My dog's honour has been cleared. I say to the McKeon family: I do not know what part of Sydney you live in now; but I have squared the account tonight.

I do not know who the senior Australian Labor Party sources quoted are. Quite frankly, I care not because, if I am a lone crusader, I believe I am in damned good company with several of my colleagues such as Senators Georges, McIntosh and Sibraa, all of whom have voiced concern about the matter which has seen the misconduct of senior officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs. Those officers have repeatedly robbed the taxpayers and, through the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street), have misled the Parliament, abused parliamentary privilege and told lies to the Senate. My calls for the suspension from duty of those officers and the implementation of a thorough and impartial investigation into the misconduct which has gone on for years have been resisted, avoided and latterly ignored by Mr Street and other Ministers.

Allegations by Senator Primmer

Kevin Newman MP, to ask him to have investigated by the Australian Federal Police the allegations made by Senator Primmer in the Senate on 25 November against officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs. Mr Street said that he and the officers concerned regarded the allegations as most serious ones and were anxious that they should be investigated immediately.

Thus, based on Mr Street's telephone call and his subsequent Press release, I expected that Mr Street had realised that the Tehran affair had to be re-opened, as I have urged for some time. However, my hopes fell when I read Mr Street's letter to Mr Newman which, in effect, limited the new investigations to the allegations of the local businessman of fraud by Mr Bowden and matters concerning Mr Loveday. In other words, the unspoken point was that the Tehran affair was over and done with and that both Mr Bowden and Mr Henderson had been cleared by the Department of Finance and the police. That I deny, and I accuse Mr Street of having misled the Parliament, the media and the taxpayer in his Press release. Nevertheless, I felt that I should co-operate with the police to the maximum extent possible in their investigations of the two new matters-the alleged silverware fraud and the alleged holiday trip, at the taxpayers' expense , to Austria by Mr Loveday and his wife, using an official car and a driver. Further, I informed them that there was information from a very senior source concerning a false invalidity retirement orchestrated by Mr Henderson for a close friend and colleague, Sir Nicholas Parkinson. I have sought full information on these matters by placing questions on notice to the Minister.

Let me make it clear that the latter matter seems to involve many thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money. I ask: Does this demonstrate that Mr Henderson was prepared to use taxpayers' money to obtain his present position as Secretary to the Department of Foreign Affairs? Whilst I do not want to impinge on Sir Nicholas's privacy by discussing his health, in my view the matter raises questions and there is an urgent need for an investigation by some authority, not influenced by Mr Henderson or his Department, into this matter. Likewise, with all the matters that I have raised since February of this year, let Mr Street and the Government undertake a full inquiry by a completely impartial body into all the allegations which have been made. I refer to allegations by staff of the Department of Foreign Affairs that both Mr Henderson and Mr R. J. Smith have breached section after section of the Crimes Act; allegations of the misuse of government funds by a handful of senior public servants and the subsequent cover-up of same by permanent departmental heads and Ministers of this Government; allegations of the misuse of security personnel within the Department and the purveying of lies to the Parliament; legal action and threats of same against the media and a parliamentary representative; continual maltreatment of actual and potential witnesses; a despicable rumour campaign against some officers of the Department; and, in the case of Mr Henderson, barefaced lying to a Senate committee. He made the point tonight that he was rather upset by or regretted very much the form of that inquiry. It seems to me that the recourse which he has in these circumstances is to bring forth positive evidence which amounts to something more than assertion and which would justify the Government's involvement in any further activity or investigation.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the further assertions that Senator Primmer made in the Parliament tonight in relation to certain officers, again I invite him to produce evidence of any kind that will serve to back them up. He rightly drew our attention to the powers of the Parliament in relation to privilege. He is fully entitled to put forward his views in the way that he did tonight. However, I believe that he owes it to all of us who are members of this place to bring forward evidence which can be rightly the subject of a proper inquiry and which can be determined on the value of the evidence itself. We should all regard assertions as being less than positive evidence. All of us should keep our assertions close to ourselves until we are absolutely certain of the way in which we should put them forward in this place. We should have regard to the fact that this place is terribly powerful in the way that its proceedings are reported. We know of the privilege that exists in respect of individual honourable senators. We know that whatever we say in this place can be reported without punishment for those who might report it. In that respect, I believe we have to be very careful in the way that we handle ourselves. Nevertheless, the allegations that have been made are very serious. I would very much like Senator Primmer to bring forward further evidence so that the Government might consider it in the light of his allegations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.52 p.m.
